article.value: Folk and local motifs also appeared in the various arts such as architecture, sculpture, and paintings. The churches built all over the country exhibit the blend of Philippine folk and European classical or baroque. For instance, the relief stone carvings on the main pediment of the Miag-ao church in Iloilo feature a lively folk motif in the figure of Saint Christopher carrying the Child Jesus under a coconut tree in combination with curving balustrade motifs and ornate baroque medallions. The same decorative spirit is found in the church retablos (altarpieces, usually with niches for statues) ornamented with gilded Solomonic columns topped by broken pediments. The relleves or holy images in relief and icons or paintings on wood sport curlicues in floral motifs for their borders. The same is true for silver ornaments, for altars in the ornate plateresque style of the silversmiths, as well as for the carrozas (floats) that bore the saints in procession. The santos (religious figures) enshrined in church retablos or displayed on private altars showed the convergence of East and West. In churches, statues in the formal style, done under the strict supervision of the ecclesiastical authorities, followed European aesthetic canons. Classical santos followed the prescribed proportions for the figure and conveyed the values of restraint and cool elegance, while those showing baroque influence, whether in wood or in ivory, had an emotional, expressionistic character. On the other hand, informal or folk santos drew from the indigenous sculpture styles of the angular and squat anitos with round preternatural eyes. The main reason for church supervision of religious art was to prevent the entry of unorthodox elements in church iconography.

The folk arts that fused the indigenous and the colonial elements found expression primarily in the many productions that revolved around the fiestas (religious festivals). A multitude of folk arts was developed with bright colors and exuberant forms and shapes. Outstanding were the Christmas lanterns or parol, the decorated Lenten palm fronds or palaspas, the colorful papier-mâché horses or taka, tinapay ni San Nicolas (San Nicolas cookies), pastillas (candy made from carabao milk) with cutout wrappers, and brightly colored native delicacies or sapin-sapin. These arts continue to the present in regional folk art centers such as Paete, known for wood carving and taka. In Angono, a lakeshore town, the harvest festival brings out papier-mâché giants and carabaos in a parade. In the Quezon towns of Lucban and Sariaya, the Maytime fiesta of San Isidro Labrador decks the houses in kiping, colorful leaf shapes made of rice flour formed into chandeliers called arangya and floral bouquets, covering all available space on the walls together with the harvest of fruits and grains, handicrafts, and other products of the town. The art of lantern making has culminated in the huge Christmas lanterns of San Fernando, Pampanga, which are virtual kaleidoscopes of color and movement synchronized by music.

In the Visayas, other centers of folk art related to church fiestas are Kalibo, Aklan, where the Christ child is honored with the Ati-atihan festival in January. The participants don the most spectacular costumes and headdresses in a combination of feathers, beads, and boar’s teeth as in primitive art, while bodies are blackened with soot. In the towns of Marinduque, the Moriones festival, based on the story of Longinus, is characterized by wooden masks in strong colors that resemble Roman centurions with their towering headdresses. These folk arts that fuse the indigenous and the colonial with their Christian subjects were established to win the people over to Christianity. Wood carving as folk art is also practiced in the Laguna towns of Paete and Pakil, and in Betis, Pampanga. Paete wood-carvers perfected the art of carving santos from native hardwoods. After the initial coating of glue and plaster of paris (gesso) to create a nonporous ground, the work of the encarnador (finisher) consists in giving the image a rosy lifelike hue or ivory finish. A neighboring town, Pakil, is known for its fans and toothpick trees of exquisite filigree of wood from the light-toned matang-araw and cayetana trees of the Sierra Madre, as well as for its intricately carved bakya or wooden slippers, while the Betis wood-carvers apply their skills to urban sala sets and dining tables.

With the formal opening of the country to international trade in the mid-19th century, significant economic change came about with cash-crop agriculture. With the independence of Mexico and the loss of the royal subsidy for the Philippines, Spain let go of its monopoly on trade and opened the ports of the country. Foreign merchant houses owned by the British, French, Germans, and Americans established their offices along Manila Bay and stimulated the cash economy. The new situation opened positions for local agents and dealers to serve as liaison for the merchants. Moneylenders, mostly Chinese mestizos, flourished. Landlords converted from the traditional produce of rice to the new export crops in demand, such as sugar, coffee, abaca, and copra. The quota system was introduced thereby applying greater pressure on the peasant farmers. The surplus from the sale of the cash crops was accrued to the ilustrado (educated) class whose members became the new patrons of the arts. Higher education in the universities in Manila or abroad, in Spain and France, became accessible with the opening of the Suez Canal in 1859. The resulting culture developed new tastes geared toward Western aesthetics and art forms. At the same time, they became exposed in Europe to liberal ideas and spearheaded the reform movement.

An important effect of cash-crop agriculture was the boom in the construction of the bahay na bato, the mansion of wood and stone that confidently combined indigenous features with classical and baroque elements. For its well-appointed interiors, the ilustrados commissioned retratos or portraits. Portraits flourished in this period and artists ably met the demand, sometimes traveling to different towns to do commissions. Favored painters were Simon Flores y de la Rosa, Antonio Malantic, Justiniano Asuncion, Dionisio de Castro, and Ysidro Arceo, to mention a few. They worked in a style called miniaturismo derived from the miniaturist’s art of limning, which gives meticulous attention to details of costume, embroidery, and textures to fashion accessories and jewelry, as well as domestic furnishings and various objets d’arts. Among the outstanding portraits of the period were Simon Flores’s Quiason Family, 1880; Antonio Malantic’s Inocencia and Soledad Francia, both done in 1876; Dionisio de Castro’s Soterania Puson y Quintos de Ventenilla, 1892; and Justiniano Asuncion’s Romana Carillo, 1870. These images reflected a dynamic stage in the development of the Filipino identity.

Along with the secularization of art, painters opened their ateliers to students who wished to study art. Along with Faustino Quiotan, one of the earliest art teachers was Damian Domingo who founded the original Academia de Dibujo y Pintura (Academy of Drawing and Painting) around 1823. After his early death, however, it was taken over by the Sociedad Economica de Amigos del Pais (Economic Society of Friends of the Country) whose administration patterned it after the Academia de San Fernando (Academy of San Fernando) in Madrid and invited Spanish teachers Cortina and Nieto to teach. They were later followed by Agustin Saez and Lorenzo Rocha. The academy had many students, among them Juan Luna and Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, along with several women artists.

Of those who went to Spain, Juan Luna and Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, two expatriate artists, won honors at the Madrid Exposition of 1884. Luna was awarded the first gold medal for his Spoliarium and Hidalgo a silver for his Las Virgenes Cristianas Expuestas al Populacho (Christian Virgins Exposed to the Crowd). Luna also painted La Muerte de Cleopatra (The Death of Cleopatra), which also won him a silver medal in the Madrid Exposition of 1881. Hidalgo is also known for other big canvases, like El Asesinato del Gobernador Fernando Bustamante Y Su Hijo (The Assassination of Governor Fernando Bustamante and Son), done in the late 19th century, portraying a violent episode in 1719. Hidalgo painted the later capitulationist Per Pacem et Libertatem (Through Peace and Liberty) in 1903. Triumphs of Luna and Hidalgo were inspirational to Filipinos who needed the affirmation that it was possible to surpass the colonial masters.

Not long after, in 1896, the Philippine Revolution was launched against Spain. Symbols that were associated with the Katipunan and the struggles of the Filipino masses derived from indigenous images and syllabary. From this tradition came the reconfigured revolutionary Christ and Virgin Mary garbed in a Filipino dress of the Aglipayan church, which continue to be meaningful to various communities in the Philippines.
The Visual Arts during the American Occupation

The gains of the Philippine Revolution of 1896 were thwarted by the United States (US) who crushed native resistance in the Philippine-American War, forcibly occupied the country, and established a colonial government. Colonial strategy lay primarily in the domain of ideology and culture. This was implemented through the public school system and educational programs. The colonial project included the participation of the Philippines in the Saint Louis World’s Fair in 1904 in Missouri. At the fair, various indigenous groups were forced to perform their ethnicity as America’s “other.” The colonized Filipinos became the subject of photography seen through the lens of American soldiers, journalists, and anthropologists, constructing the image of the Filipino as an inferior race that needs American tutelage and benevolence. In the visual arts, there was a demand for illustrations and cartoons for the textbooks and publications of the period. To answer the needs of the new corporations, commercial art and advertising design were integrated into the fine arts curriculum. The Academia de Dibujo y Pintura was transformed into the School of Fine Arts of the University of the Philippines, one of the first units of the institution. The first director was Don Fabian de la Rosa who painted excellent country landscapes and genre scenes. He also continued the tradition of tipos del pais (country scenes), which consisted of a range of Filipino physical types, which were mainly academic exercises but with aesthetic value. The secretary of the college for a long period was Jose Ma. Asuncion, a member of the Asuncion family of artists. Guillermo Tolentino and Fernando Amorsolo also became its directors.

During the American period, landscapes, genre paintings, and portraiture prevailed. Fernando Amorsolo, the foremost exponent of the school, painted colorful rural scenes characterized by backlighting, as in Planting Rice, 1921, while in his portrait of Fernanda de Jesus, 1915, he upheld the paradigm of the dalagang bukid or country maiden with its conservative feudal values regarding women’s role in society. Amorsolo landscapes and portraits were much sought-after by the elite, American officials, and tourists as these served as souvenirs of the colony.

In sculpture, the dominant personality was Guillermo Tolentino who was trained in the classical tradition in Rome. He did a number of works such as the UP Oblation, 1935, and Venus, 1951, as well as numerous busts and life-size statues of public figures such as President Quezon. However, he is best known for the Bonifacio Monument, 1933, in Caloocan rotunda completed on the eve of the Commonwealth. Expressing nationalist fervor in the struggle against colonial rule, it was in consonance with the spirit of the period. Bonifacio, at the center of the storm, is surrounded by episodes or stages of the revolution from the execution of Fathers Jose Burgos, Jacinto Zamora, and Mariano Gomez, or the GomBurZa, to the uprising of the revolutionary Katipunan. Anastacio Caedo, an apprentice of Tolentino, followed this approach. Another sculptor of the period was Ramon Martinez who did the single-figure prototype sculpture of Bonifacio, one arm raising a bolo, originally meant for Balintawak.

The dominance of Amorsolo was challenged by Victorio Edades who introduced modernism in the country. Fresh from the United States in 1928, Edades had an exhibit at the Philippine Columbian. Edades, an advocate of modern art, triggered a lively press debate between conservatives who followed Amorsolo and modernists who were drawn to his principles. Edades, whose influence lay primarily in his role as educator, stressed that the subject of art goes beyond the beautiful and harmonious to include the ugly and the terrible. He asserted the importance of design and formal elements underlying modern art. He also had the vision of developing Filipino identity in art.
The Visual Arts during the Japanese Occupation

The Philippines under Japanese occupation experienced a cultural overhaul wherein all Western influences were abandoned. Paintings during this period showed conformity to Japanese mores. Works by Gregorio Sibug and Vicente Alvarez Dizon, for instance, highlighted Japanese policies while works by Fernando Amorsolo, Marcelino Rivera, Emilio Santiago, and Cirilo Santiago emphasized Filipino traditions and values. Cartoonists such as EZ Izon and Liborio Gatbonton worked for the Japanese-censored Tribune, highlighting government policies and projects. Connoisseurs and patrons such as Jorge Vargas, Aurelio Alvero, and Jose Bantug continued to support the arts. Art criticism was kept alive as evidenced by critical exchanges between art critics. Many artists found ways to eke out a living during this difficult time. Carlos “Botong” Francisco worked for Manuel Conde, designing billboards, sets, and posters for stage plays. Manuel Rodriguez Sr opened an art school in Naga and later made and sold brooches, fans, and bakya in Manila.

While Filipino artists had no choice but to acquiesce, they also managed to resist Japanese rule. Galo B. Ocampo did underground work for the US Army Forces in the Far East and Izon illustrated for the Japanese underground paper The Liberator. Subtle messages of subversion were also incorporated in the works of Izon and Gatbonton in the Tribune. But it was only after the war ended that artists were able to give free rein to their emotions by depicting Japanese atrocities in their works.
Republic III: 1946-72

The uncertainty and the unrest resulting from the war were harnessed by modernists using techniques of distortion. Modernists and conservatives thwarted content and any moral or utilitarian function during the disruptive aftermath, a period wherein form and self-expression prevailed. In addition, after the granting of formal independence by the United States of America and while Manila was still in ruins, the question of national identity was posed by writers and artists. In fact, the first impetus to modernism was coupled with the quest for identity, which artists dealt with in various ways: through subject matter, content, and form. Along with this issue was the debate between proletarian art and art for art’s sake, which emerged with the widespread poverty of the period.

Modern painting grew with the Triumvirate formed by Victorio Edades, Carlos “Botong” Francisco, and Galo B. Ocampo who in 1930 collaborated on commissioned murals for the State and Capitol Theaters, in which the public was first exposed to modern art with an Art Deco influence. Meanwhile press debates on conservatism versus modernism were resumed after the war. In painting, Edades demonstrated his modernist style primarily in The Builders and The Artist and His Model, both dated 1928. Angono-based Francisco did the magnificent historical mural 500 Years of Philippine History, the first of its kind, for the 1953 Manila International Fair. This was followed in 1969 by the History of the Struggles of the Filipino People for the Bulwagang Katipunan of the Manila City Hall during the time of Mayor Antonio Villegas. The second mural is divided into the various episodes of Philippine history and its central figures. Carlos Francisco also did many genre murals celebrating Filipino customs and festivals in his style of fluid curvilinear lines, graceful figures, and tropical colors. He drew most of his subjects from the life of his lakeshore town, and gave to genre painting a rich particularity of detail of the customs, traditions, and material culture of fishermen and farmers. Galo B. Ocampo is best remembered for his Brown Madonna, 1938, giving the traditional religious subject a Filipino iconography, and for his painting series Ecce Homo, 1950, alluding to the war. A later series was the Tabon Man, 1970s, an homage to the earliest human fossil found in the Philippines, as well as to the primeval roots of the Filipino people’s ancestors.

article.value: Also after the war, the Thirteen Moderns pursued the campaign for modernism and constituted a new generation after the Amorsolo School. Merged with the original Triumvirate were the names of Arsenio Capili, Bonifacio Cristobal, Demetrio Diego, Cesar Legaspi, Diosdado M. Lorenzo, Anita Magsaysay-Ho, Vicente Manansala, H.R. Ocampo, Jose Pardo, and Ricarte Puruganan. There was an earlier effort to organize under the Atelier of Modern Art headed by Diosdado M. Lorenzo with Victorio Edades and Carlos Francisco but World War II disrupted the initiative. Other noted abstract artists during this period were Romeo Tabuena, Federico Alcuaz, Fernando Zobel, Constancio Bernardo, Arturo Luz, Cenon Rivera, and Victor Oteyza.

The support system for modern art was laid down with the founding of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) by Purita Kalaw-Ledesma. It began a highly successful annual art competition, which welcomed modernist as well as conservative artists. Complementing the AAP was the Philippine Art Gallery founded by Lydia Villanueva-Arguilla. As the pioneering gallery, it provided a venue for fledgling modernists and curated the first shows. A third important venue was the Contemporary Art Gallery founded and run by Manuel Rodriguez Sr, which specialized in printmaking and offered continual workshops to disseminate the art form. The tension between the conservatives and modernists came to a head in 1959 during the semiannual art competition sponsored by the Art Association of the Philippines. The conservatives staged a walkout to protest the perceived bias of the jury who awarded most of the prizes to the modernists. The conservatives set up the Mabini Artists group.

While the main protagonists in painting were Amorsolo and Edades, in sculpture it was Tolentino and his pupil Napoleon Abueva. The latter championed modernist values in sculpture while striving for a Filipino idiom. Abueva has worked with a wide variety of materials and techniques, although his personal preference is wood, mainly narra and molave, carved directly by chisel. He has also worked with adobe and alabaster, different kinds of metal (brass, bronze, and aluminum), as well as concrete. Abueva’s work is characterized by playfulness and charming wit, often integrating sculptural and functional aspects.

Popular art was also alive during this period with komiks continuing to gain ground, especially among the masses, because of its visuality, affordability, and availability. The humorous, historical, and fantasy themes of komiks in the postwar period provided a convenient escape from the harsh realities of life. Tony Velasquez’s Kenkoy, Francisco Coching’s El Indio, and Mars Ravelo’s Darna exemplify these themes. It was also an active period for journalism, with the major dailies churning out creative and original editorial cartoons by artists like Larry Alcala, Malang, and Corky Trinidad.

In the 1950s, a number of artists formed a subgroup called the Neo-Realists consisting of Vicente Manansala, H.R. Ocampo, and Cesar Legaspi. Influenced by cubism, they sought to explore modernist styles of approaching the figure. They arrived at the style called transparent cubism, which fused the cubist structuring of the figure with transparent effects, resulting in the indigenization of the original School of Paris style. It is often observed that, unlike European cubism which fragmented the human form, the cubism of the Neo-Realists did more than cut up forms—they reorganized them into facets or transparent planes. One artist who showed cubist influence was Federico Aguilar Alcuaz who spent many years in Europe, where he designed abstract tapestries. Vicente Manansala expanded the subject matter of art, culling inspiration from the rural idylls of the Amorsolo School to the postwar urban realities of jeepneys recycled from the war, candle and amulet vendors in Quiapo (which was the hub of economic struggle), to the patchwork barong-barong (shanties) in Manila, which appeared following postwar displacement and poverty. H.R. Ocampo worked on proletarian art showing the poor and the stark social contrasts in the urban setting. One of the important works to come out of the period, Calvary, 1948, shows Christ on the cross, flanked by the two thieves against a background of factories spewing forth noxious orange fumes. He subsequently moved away from social themes and sought to develop a Filipino abstract idiom. Later, he became widely known for an abstract style of interlocking colored planes, as in his Genesis, 1969, curtain design for the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Cesar Legaspi traversed different periods in his works during the development of his modernist idiom. Legaspi created proletarian art with his painting The Beggars (also titled The Kiss), 1945, showing two wretched figures huddled among the ruins in monochrome brown with cubist fragmentation. Later works drew their imagery from stone quarries and carved tribal icons in the search for basic origins. After experimental works in sculptured surfaces, Legaspi explored rhythmic figures in richly orchestrated tones and colors. Later, he painted the dynamic Jeepney series with suggestions of street graffiti in neorealist style.

Another neorealist, Romeo Tabuena was known for delicate watercolors of the rural scene. Subjects consisted mainly of rice fields with carabaos and nipa huts in an early morning haze as though forms are emerging from the mist—a style that combined exquisite linearity with tonal effects. But he also worked in an intense, vigorous style in dark tones and harsh, bold strokes diametrically different from the first, and in which he depicted sun-shriveled peasants and gnarled workers. This was also an active period for Anita Magsaysay-Ho displaying a distinct genre of etherealized female peasants in various rural activities. But she had earlier worked in a more vigorous style influenced by the New York School of the 1950s and its association with the painterly abstract expressionism. She also went through a nocturnal period of women selling their wares, primarily birds in cages as though etched in the darkness.

A branch of modernism was abstract art, the major proponents of which in the 1950s were Jose Joya and Constancio Bernardo. Joya was strongly influenced by New York abstract expressionism. Federico Aguilar Alcuaz alternated between abstract and figurative painting in many landscapes done during sojourns abroad and charming genre scenes of women. Carnival Forms, 1956, by Arturo Luz showed greater texture and density but retained a linear character. Next, Luz approached his work with burlap collages and calligraphic works on handmade paper. He was also known for his sculptures ranging from large outdoor works to small silver pieces.

The 1960s was characterized by the rise of second-generation abstractionists Jose Joya, Lee Aguinaldo, Mauro Malang, Ang Kiukok, Veronica Yu, and younger artists using different styles like Ben Cabrera (aka BenCab), Antonio Austria, Roberto Chabet, Norma Belleza, and Justin Nuyda. In the field of sculpture, J. Elizalde Navarro, Edgar Doctor, David Medalla, and Eduardo Castrillo caught the public’s attention.

The Cultural Center of the Philippines was opened in 1969 as the most visible symbol of state patronage. Under Roberto Chabet and later Raymundo Albano, the CCP opened its exhibition programming to works influenced by Western avant-garde and conceptual tenets. Chabet initiated and maintained an experimental and conceptual approach with a valorization of materials and their semiotic potentials. Aguinaldo kept in close touch with art trends in the United States, churning out works that called to mind the “zip” paintings of Barnett Newman. Alfredo Roces, known for figurative landscapes and still lifes, maintained a highly personal and original approach to his art. At the heels of the first-generation modernists followed a more audacious, younger breed. Ang Kiukok, Onib Olmedo, Jaime de Guzman, and Danilo Dalena worked in expressionist styles with high visual impact. In contrast, BenCab developed a highly original idiom that combined realism with experimental devices to enrich the significations of the artworks.

In the climate of the Cold War, the nuclear threat, and American aggression in Vietnam, Ang Kiukok crystallized in vivid, cubist figures the terror and angst of the times. Ang Kiukok figures were strongly structured and concentrated in composition, often symbolic in content, with contrasting hues that conveyed emotional conflict. Jaime de Guzman painted historical murals of the 19th-century propaganda movement and revolution against Spain in a painterly, expressionistic style. Gifted with a sense of locale, he also celebrated Mount Banahaw, home to many folk cults, in paintings with indigenous symbols. Another strong artistic personality who lent brilliance to the 1960s was Danilo Dalena. A political cartoonist, he is known for paintings of large crowds of people in quest of luck or miracles and of unflinchingly realist character studies and drawings of the steamy side of the city. It was primarily Dalena who carried on the tradition in popular forms begun in the 1960s and resumed in the 1970s by the modernists. Ben Cabrera, in his low-key but intellectually experimental style, explored images of the Filipino in prints and watercolors inspired by turn-of-the-century photographs that he analyzed, drawing out a rich semiotic vocabulary with which he made subtle, ironic comments on the colonial relationship and the question of national identity. Another contemporary, Onib Olmedo portrayed the down-and-out, the street hawkers, and nocturnal denizens with the use of expressionist distortion.
Republic IV: 1972-86

Escalating mass protests against the worsening economic crisis led to the First Quarter Storm of 1970. The US-supported Marcos government responded to the highly charged political climate by declaring martial law in 1972 and establishing a conjugal dictatorship. Most of the artists who emerged in the 1960s continued to produce important work in the 1970s through the martial law years.

In assessing the social and political situation, a number of artists maintained the importance of an art responsible to society and to the issues and concerns of the times. The social realists who grouped together in the 1970s were not an entirely new force since they firmed up the postwar direction in “proletarian art” and expanded the nationalist themes of older artists like Cesar Legaspi and Hernando Ocampo. To the Kaisahan (Solidarity) social realist group belonged Pablo Baens Santos, Edgar Talusan Fernandez, Papo de Asis, Orlando Castillo, Antipas Delotavo, Renato Habulan, Neil Doloricon, Al Manrique, and Jose Tence Ruiz. Aside from them, there were other serious artists who produced or continued to produce significant works of social consciousness. A work that exemplified the period is Delotavo’s Itak sa Puso ni Mang Juan (Knife in Juan’s Heart), 1978, depicting a downtrodden Filipino worker oppressed by the economic tyranny of multinational corporations in the country.

At the same time, numerous artists were caught up in active state patronage of the arts and in the state-sponsored building boom, which resulted in a lucrative partnership between interior designers and artists. For one, the martial law years were marked by a high degree of tourism consciousness. The CCP Complex was part of the building boom, which began in 1969. Mrs Marcos used the CCP to project the image of the state as benevolent patron of the arts and to support state cultural ideology. Genre paintings flourished in this decade with highly original approaches seen in the work of Norma Belleza, Angelito Antonio, Antonio Austria, Mario Parial, Manuel Baldemor, and Mauro Malang Santos.

Paintings also conveyed a genuine feeling for the city folk with their small trades and modest pastimes, as in the subject of vendors and cockfighters popularized by Manansala, as well as folk traditions. There was an evident self-confidence and zest on the part of the artists in breaking away from the academic conventions and creating new figurative styles more suitable to their folk subjects. A particular group represented the trend in “vanishing scene” paintings, which rendered old churches, landmarks, and ancestral houses in meticulous detail. This kind of painting with an underlying documentary impulse was pursued by Al Perez and Elmer Gernale. While Lino Severino, a painter, was one of the first to do this type of work, he did not only render material appearance but also captured the mood and atmosphere of old crumbling structures, especially turn-of-the-century houses, by means of fine tonalities in monochrome.

Abstract art continued primarily with the influence of Jose Joya, who had earlier caused a stir with bold paintings in the abstract expressionist style driven by kinetic impulse, as in Hills of Nikko, 1964. Later, he moved to a more harmonious idiom in acrylic and rice paper collages that played on transparent and overlapping colored forms in space. Artists Lao Lianben, Augusto Albor, Mars Galang, Glenn Bautista, Justin Nuyda, and Phillip Victor also worked in developing their own abstract idioms. Albor opted for a minimalist abstraction in black and white, using a variety of materials including reflecting surfaces. Lao Lianben worked in wood with relief elements and found objects, at times singed and scratched, in contrasting black and white. Zen was an abiding influence in his work, which is based on a few significant signs. Phillip Victor developed a new medium of white-embossed paintings with nature symbols and small color accents in abstract landscapes recalling the fish ponds of his native Bulacan.

A number of artists took up the ethnic theme, following the example of Muslim painter and sculptor Abdulmari Imao. His themes were inspired by the life and culture of the fishing villages of Sulu and Lanao in Mindanao. He is best known for his series on the sarimanok, a principal cultural symbol derived from the ancient legends of Mindanao and Sulu. He introduced innovations in brassware among the craftsmen of Tugaya, Lanao.

Continuing from the 1960s, Manuel Rodriguez Sr’s printmaking workshop at the Contemporary Art Gallery promoted the development of graphic arts. Another senior printmaker was Rodolfo Paras-Perez who produced an outstanding series of woodcuts of expressionist influence. Soon, members of the Philippine Association of Printmakers were producing works in etching and aquatint, collographs, embossments, and woodcuts. Among the artists who trained in the workshops were Virgilio Aviado, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Brenda Fajardo, Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi, Impy Pilapil, and Fil Delacruz. Aviado’s style ranged from highly detailed surrealist compositions to minimal constructions of paper collage. Imelda Cajipe-Endaya has explored the question of national identity in etching and serigraphy. Brenda Fajardo’s prints at first showed the influence of classical figuration before she shifted to folk forms of representation, such as tarot figures. Based in Paris, Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi worked in the color viscosity printing technique, which makes possible simultaneous printing in different colors. She has also dealt with the question of Filipino identity and the threat of nuclear devastation in the Cold War. Impy Pilapil did cosmic landscapes in serigraphy, sometimes using origami-like elements. A printmaker who revived the mezzotint technique is Fil Delacruz who did works inspired by his sojourn among the tribal Filipino groups in Mindanao. He favored mezzotint for its wider and finer range of black-and-white tones that convey mood and atmosphere. These printmakers developed Philippine themes, drawing inspiration from indigenous and folk culture, as well as making comment on contemporary realities.

A number of sculptors also emerged in the same productive decade. Lamberto Hechanova innovated in the use of metal and plastics in sculpture. Virginia Ty-Navarro worked in new techniques in wood with an in-carved intaglio method also done in metal with a pointillist approach, using beads of molten metal to shape figures on a basic framework. J. Elizalde Navarro pioneered in highly expressive wood and metal assemblages. Ty-Navarro was also known for her metal sculptures of birdds. Francisco Verano was among the first to use bamboo in sculpture, as in his Bamboo Fugue in the CCP. Eduardo Castrillo produced a sizeable body of work, including monumental sculptures of religious themes for memorial parks, large open-form abstracts of welded metal, mobiles and modular pieces in chrome and plexiglass, metal relief sculptures of social themes, and sculptured body jewelry. Solomon Saprid created metal sculptures around the theme of the tikbalang, a mythological “half-human half-horse” creature. Ramon Orlina who trained in architecture developed glass sculpture in freestanding works or as elements of architectural design. Printmaker Impy Pilapil transposed her earlier themes to glass etching, which she combined with rocks for contrasting texture and three-dimensional form. Julie Lluch has consistently pursued her art with personal expressionist works and accomplishments in portraiture in the terra-cotta medium. Other sculptors who deserve mention are Noel El Farol who works in glass and Gerry Leonardo who works in resin.

The large-scale anger that followed the assassination of former senator Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino Jr in 1983 saw the proliferation of street rallies. Continuing through to and particularly evident during the post-Marcos period, protest art in the form of murals and effigies became the means to express dissatisfaction with the political situation. Underground publications also used the graphic arts to explain social and political issues, not just as protest to the Marcos dictatorship but to advance a revolutionary struggle to change the social conditions of Philippine society itself. Artists who worked for various causes at this time would plant the seeds of regional art groups and alternative ways of practicing art.
Republic V: 1986 Onward

The mid-1980s saw major upheavals in Philippine sociopolitical life. The 1986 EDSA Revolt that overthrew President Ferdinand Marcos and his dictatorial regime built high hopes for changes in governance and the realization of artistic freedom. This resulted in a reorientation of vision, mission, and goals of cultural institutions, such as the Cultural Center of the Philippines, to promote democratization and decentralization of creativity and art management in the country. In 1992, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) was created to address these issues as well as implement the National Artist Awards and the Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan. An important development in this period is a growing recognition of the range of art forms that broadened the definition of the visual arts. Rather than being limited to two-dimensional and three-dimensional art forms, the visual arts now include video work, sound, performance, and the participatory experience, such as video art, sound art, performance art, installation art, and site-specific art. Reflecting the rise of installation art was the First Bagasbas International Eco-Arts Festival held in Bagasbas in Daet, Camarines Norte, 2008, arguably prequeled by Siteworks in UP Los Baños, Laguna three decades prior. Interestingly, both site projects consisted mainly of locally sourced materials. In Bagasbas, it consisted mainly of bamboo constructions along the beach which interacted, through the artists’ creativity, with the entire environment of land and sea. Participating artists in the first edition were Ronaldo Ruiz, Alfredo Juan Aquilizan, Henri Cainglet, Hermisanto, Edille Paras, Diokno Pasilan, and Tony Twigg.

Curatorial practice expanded with artist-curators working with alternative spaces for exhibitions rather than in traditional museums and galleries. Artworks were increasingly embedded in urban and community spaces, and public festival sites while also becoming more frequently upheld as commodities in market venues like auctions and art fairs. Meanwhile, regional art groups as well as urban artist formations, which advocated a definition of art that serves the needs of their communities, also flourished. Responding to various issues of poverty, environmental degradation, social inequities, and continuing struggle for human rights, these groups formed collectives and networks to create art platforms rather than art shows. This is exemplified by the activities of the now defunct Black Artists in Asia of Negros, whose members included Charlie Co and Nunelucio Alvarado, and the Baguio Arts Guild, whose members included Santiago Bose, Kidlat Tahimik, Roberto Villanueva, John Frank Sabado, and BenCab. Spaces for art would open up such as in the exhibits of the Silangan Foundation for the Arts, Culture and Ecology, based in Antipolo, which showcased a diversely aligned set of then emerging artists such as Salvador Alonday, Elmer Borlongan, Emmanuel Garibay, Mark Justiniani, Antonio Leaño, and Jose Santos III.

article.value: Women artists during this period redefined art production and reception through the group Kababaihan sa Bagong Sining at Bagong Sibol na Kamalayan (Kasibulan), founded in 1989. Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Ofelia Galvezon-Tequi, Brenda Fajardo, Julie Lluch, Lydia Ingle, and many others challenged male-centered narratives by bringing to the fore women’s lives and experiences as part of political discourse. Highlighting the global network for the advocacy of women’s voices, the exhibit Trauma Interrupted, 2007, held at the CCP, gathered several artists from different countries to present works in which women both evoked and worked out their experiences of oppression brought on by war and patriarchy.

In 2005, Karen Flores and Manny Garibay organized a series of Tutok shows, such as Tutok: Kasaysayan (Focus: History) dealing with historical issues. Its earlier project was Tutok: Karapatan (Focus: Human Rights), which tackled the extrajudicial killings of journalists and progressive community leaders. Following its success, the artist-organizers under the aegis of the Constantino Foundation continued on with the advocacy work of the Tutok series, which, like the first, brought together young and mid-career artists to harness their art's potency in popular education.

The millennium years have been witness to a dynamic reconfiguration of artistic energies, influenced by a boom in the art market and the heady auctions in Hong Kong and Singapore. Art competitions sponsored by big corporations and banks, such as Shell, Petron, Metrobank, and the Philippine Art Awards (Philip Morris Group of Companies), developed mechanisms that recognized new and young talents and rewarded the accomplishment of elders. The participation of Filipino artists in international biennales and triennales as well as the upsurge in the global trafficking of art commercially also affected the international circulation of Philippine art.

Artists are now more thoughtfully exploring the theme of national identity, mining and transforming materials and themes. Santiago Bose’s anting-anting trope, for instance, brings out these political tensions not only in terms of the imagery but in the active approach to enable meaning through working with the material and ground, which is molded, scarified, gouged, fired, layered, and variously distressed with scratches, erasures, scribbles, and burns in a highly material kind of semiotics. Consistently the major proponents of the use of indigenous materials in their work are Paz Abad Santos and Junyee, although Abad Santos has also geared her art to therapy in her work on color recognition for the blind. Another artist, the late Pacita Abad, excelled in trapunto through which she created a prodigious body of fabric art.

The search and desire for creative material has led artists to probe both site and history. Still another parallel practice is that of Alwin Reamillo who conceptualized and realized the installation Mang Emo + Mag-himo Grand Piano Project, 2007, featuring assemblage-composites of an upright piano and a grand piano in two spaces, CCP and Galleria Duemila, complete with performances by musicians. Its background is supported by the artist’s family roots in the piano-making industry in the Philippines. Another artist doing work in this vein is Lirio Salvador who is known for creating hybrid musical instruments that are unlike any that have been seen previously. These objects can surprisingly be played in a band.

The themes of figurative artworks during this period range from questions of identity in the global world, power relations, postcolonial interpretation of history, and the value of local knowledge in art. Nunelucio Alvarado, based in Bacolod, consistently evokes such themes and excels in the emblematic potential of his large murals, as exemplified in Duta Inde Bala (Land Not Bullets), which fuses religious imagery and revolutionary struggle.

The itinerant Manuel Ocampo’s early paintings deal with clashes of culture in colonial and multicultural contexts, especially between the dominant West and the indigenous colonized cultures, and the human suffering that ensued from such encounters. They also allude to the 20th-century holocausts, and the dictatorships that swept the globe, as well as hardbound prejudices of race and gender. This turmoil is conveyed with the use of recurrent Western and Philippine symbols.

Manny Garibay, meanwhile, interrogates the traditional identity of God and replaces it with multiple identities: as woman, as derelict, as abandoned street child. In his works, there is a constant shifting of genders, man/woman and vice versa, as well as the surprising appearance of Christ in various guises. Another peer, Elmer Borlongan, is an artist who pursues an original vision that derives from the everyday life of ordinary people. He gives his subjects a mystical dimension that makes them stand out, suggesting a strength of will that can overcome the dreary and desperate conditions of their lives. Mark Justiniani in turn has weighed in on America’s 9/11 event that shifted the political temper of international security in 21st century. Based on the artist’s personal recounting, it ironically took a long-distance call from the Philippines to relay a wake-up message about the fiery devastation in the heart of New York. Avoiding a grim approach, the artist brings to his work on the subject a surrealist seriocomic touch. For on the crumpled bed lies a grunting, half-yawning half-shrieking humanoid jolted from sleep, the bedside TV turned on by remote control and unfolding the gut-wrenching catastrophe on an otherwise uneventful morning. Among Filipino artists, it is Alfredo Esquillo who has given close scrutiny to the subject of folk religiosity. He has discovered that the folk mind is captive to a powerful triad: folk Christianity centering on the Passion of the Nazarene, the TV media, and sex.

The present barrage of media and sensory triggers have also enabled artists to bring in an abject performative mode to their work. An occasion in which Filipino artists shone before a foreign audience was the participation of the local group New World Disorder in the theater festival Trilogy of Globalization held in Hamburg, Germany, 2004. Stark visual contrasts also played an important part in one performance-installation-video of Mideo Cruz: antiseptic white walls and furniture against bloody red, sharp edges against chaos, bourgeois authority against squalid effusion, human against animal, one against many.

The interactive impulse brought on by networking technology has further heightened artists’ willingness to collaborate, though this propensity itself has underpinned analog methods such as painting. The mural Crossroads of the Filipino People, 2007, is the collective work of the Neo-Angono Artists Collective including Rommel “Wire” Tuazon, Richard Gappi, Katrina Miranda-Tuason, Michael de Guzman, and Allan G. Alcantara, a number of them fine arts graduates of the University of the Philippines. Relevant to the times, this National Press Club-commissioned mural dealt with the theme of the history of press freedom from the 19th century to the present, but this ironically became the subject of censorship. The CCP issued a statement commending the Neo-Angono Artists Collective for standing up for their rights, and enjoined the rest of the artistic community to do the same. Ironically, CCP became embroiled in another controversy concerning the closure of the exhibit Kulo (Boil), 2011, because of a contested installation work, Poleteismo (Polytheism), 2011, by Mideo Cruz. This incorporated an image of male genitalia on a Christian cross. Issues on the freedom of expression were compounded by the loud protest that came from the Catholic Church and the role of media and politicians in defining art based on diverging interests. Artists have gone through many exciting events, discoveries, and challenges that affect the production, circulation, and reception of art. While artists continue to respond to contemporary material conditions and global issues that affect the lives of all, the need for a discerning gaze and nuanced understanding of art is necessary for an integrated reading and retelling of the Filipino peoples’ multivocal stories at various periods of their collective history.

For most of humankind’s past no written history exists, so archaeologists use the fossils of vanished cultures to reconstruct times past. Scientific excavation is the chief means by which materials are methodically retrieved and meticulously recorded for analysis in the laboratory. Stratigraphy, artifact typology, thermoluminescence, and radiocarbon dating are some of the methods employed to accurately date the sites and finds. Where cultural artifacts have been removed from their original contexts, the presence of metal and Asian trade ceramics and beads, among other datable objects found in direct association with them, are used to approximate their dates. Largely due to advances in scientific research of the past 30 years, the following have emerged as some of the most important markers of the region’s ancient past.

 

Modern Early Humans

Some 50,000 years ago, modern humans—direct ancestors of Australian aborigines and Melanesians—reached Oceania from Australia. A skull in the Niah Cave in Sarawak, Malaysia, dating to around 38,000 BCE, and a skull fragment from the Tabon Cave in Palawan, dating to around 16,700 BCE, were the first direct evidences of modern early humans in Island Southeast Asia. Hunters and gatherers settled the Philippines, reaching Palawan around 47,000 years ago. In canoes or rafts, these pioneers crossed islands no more than 90 kms apart, using passageways of islands that became submerged after about 12,000 years during the late Pleistocene period. Early hunters and gatherers were basically stone toolmakers and users. However, recent studies indicate that they also used stone to make other tools out of bamboo, rattan, and wood. They caught game by trapping. Early modern humans—still hunters and gatherers—cultivated a few plants but did not yet domesticate animals.

 

Beginnings of Agriculture

After two million years in the Paleolithic stage of hunting and gathering and not long after the rise and fall of sea levels about 10,000-12,000 years ago, agriculture emerged and irreversibly changed humankind’s adaptation for survival. Out of southern China and into Taiwan around 5,500 years ago came farmers who domesticated rice and animals (pigs, dogs, and poultry), wove fiber, and knew carpentry skills. Agricultural records establish that speakers of Austronesian, the Malayo-Polynesian branch of the Austronesian language family, passed through the Philippines via Batanes and Luzon around 4,500 years ago and settled in lands occupied by hunters and gatherers. About 3,300-4,000 years ago, maritime knowledge allowed them to span out over Island Southeast Asia and the Pacific, practicing and introducing horticulture and boat-making skills as they migrated. Well before they spread beyond Luzon, however, these early agriculturalists had tools that included shell artifacts, shell and stone adzes, and gouges. They also made a variety of red-slipped, painted, impressed, incised, excised, and polished pottery.

Crossing Island Southeast Asia into the Indian and Pacific Oceans, these early agriculturalists reached Madagascar in the West by 500 CE and New Zealand (Polynesia) in the East by 1200 CE. Evidence of their presence in Melanesia was the appearance of the Lapita Culture that later spread into the uninhabited Pacific. The settlement of the Asia-Pacific region by these Austronesian speakers was the earliest and most remarkable story of maritime colonization. The Philippines as a jump-off point was vital in the transference of Austronesian cultures that eventually reached halfway around the world. A significant marker of this migration that came through the Philippines was the knowledge of jade working from Taiwan.

 

Jade Trade 2,500 Years Ago

Early artisans left evidence of an ancient workshop of green jade in Batanes, northernmost islands of the Philippines. The site was part of a trade network that survived for 2,500 years (1500 BCE through 1000 CE), which included Fengtian, Taiwan, the only known source of green jade (nephrite) in the region. The source of the white jade, used contemporaneously in the Philippines to make bracelets, adzes, beads, and the ubiquitous lingling-o ear ornaments, has not been located. Lingling-o reached the Tabon Caves in Palawan, southern Vietnam, the Niah Caves in Sarawak, southern Thailand, and possibly Cambodia. Fengtian nephrites from Taiwan initially came in the form of adzes, axes, and spear points. These were later refashioned into prestige ornaments, as evidenced in excavated sites in Batanes and nearby Lanyu island, now part of Taiwan. While green jade came to the Philippines from Taiwan, with the tradition of jade perhaps coming from China through Taiwan, early Filipinos contributed to this ancient international trade with their skill and technique, developing a style of jade carving, such as the lingling-o found in Uyaw Cave, Lipuun Point, Palawan (ca 500-300 BCE), which may have been carried to as far as Maori New Zealand.

 

Early Pottery

Early Filipinos were adept at collecting clay and forming, sun-drying, and baking earthenware in open fires. Shaping was done by hand with or without a turntable, after which the earthenware was fired in the open field using forest wood, bamboo, dry leaves, and grass. There were no kilns or ovens in prehistoric earthenware sites in the Philippines. Hand-shaping methods included coiling, pinching, pressing, molding, and slab-building. While the simple globular pot was likely the earliest and most dispersed form, presentation dishes and jarlets were also found in ancient sites. As early as 5000-1000 BCE, pottery in Taiwan, the Philippines, the island of Borneo, and other parts of Indonesia had surfaces with red slips (clay with the consistency of cream poured onto the surface) while others were impressed with patterns using cord-bound and carved paddles. By about 4780-4400 BCE, dated archaeological artifacts from the central Philippines, Cagayan Valley, and Palawan demonstrate the already widespread use of slipped, painted, impressed, incised, excised, and appliquéd pottery. Forms were not repeated in large numbers.

What began as the crafting of single pieces during the Neolithic period (4000/3000-500 BCE) evolved with technology into the sophisticated and mass-produced vessels of the late Metal Age (200 BCE-900 CE), such as the anthropomorphic burial jar from Maitum, Sarangani Province (5 BCE-370 CE). Their larger numbers, wider range of forms, and elaborately decorated surfaces characterized local pottery prior to contact with the great traditions of China and India (before 900 CE), a period popularly regarded as the golden age of Philippine pottery. The ever-increasing local demand for high-fired Chinese ceramics during the Song (906-1279), Yuan (1279-1368), and Ming (1368-1644) dynasties resulted in a leveling off of artistic culture in the region, with local pottery forms becoming simplified and their functions more utilitarian, such as the pot with inscriptions from Calatagan, Batangas (possibly 1600s). Local pottery technology did not recover until the 19th century, and only temporarily.

 

Early Interisland Trade

Ancient trade networks operated on similar economic principles as modern ones. Local pottery was a major item of commerce then as it was in historical times. In prehistory, pottery may have been more intensely manufactured during off-planting seasons with the goal of exchanging pots for other needed items. Pottery sharing traits in manufacture, form, and decoration but found in widely dispersed archaeological sites seems to indicate long-established patterns of exchange. Gleaned from these finds are networks of early interisland trade, most notably between (a) Mindoro, Batangas, Laguna, and Rizal provinces; (b) coastal northeast Panay, eastern Negros, and northwest Cebu; (c) southern Bohol, southern Leyte, and northeastern Mindanao; (d) western Bicol, northern Samar, and Marinduque; (e) the Peñablanca area of Cagayan Valley and Northern Luzon; (f) the Tabon Cave complex in Palawan; and (g) the Bacong site, Negros Oriental, and the Hoyop Hoyopan Cave in Albay.

 

Early Gold

Before ironwork in Southeast Asia, linguistic studies show that people using stone and shell implements had words to describe metal and man-made metal items. Although this cannot be dated scientifically, gold was probably the first precious metal to be shaped. Gold beads from Guri Cave in the Tabon Cave complex of southwestern Palawan are the earliest gold items associated with archaeologically excavated artifacts in what is now the Philippines. They trace back to 500-300 CE. Only from the 10th century CE onward, however, and particularly from the 12th to the 15th century, do intricately crafted gold artifacts occur plentifully in the archipelago.

 

 

Gold was abundant in the Philippines, and ancient burial customs favored adornments made from this precious metal. Worked gold was found in various parts of the archipelago: central Luzon (Novaliches, Rizal, Laguna) yielded piloncitos (tiny gold coins used by Filipinos for barter during pre-Hispanic times) similar to those found in Sri Vijayan sites (700-1377 CE); northwestern Luzon (Bolinao in Pangasinan) and southern Luzon (Sorsogon) yielded gold beads and ornaments; and the islands of Mindoro, Palawan, Cebu, Panay, and Bohol in the central Philippines yielded a variety of repoussé jewelry, beads, dental inlay, and gold sheet face covers, such as the Oton death mask (late 1500s to early 1600s). So far, excavated sites in Butuan and Surigao in northeastern Mindanao and Samar in eastern Visayas have produced the widest range and largest quantities of gold ornaments. These centers of gold production have yielded pieces unrivaled in Island Southeast Asia, evidencing sophisticated techniques like granulation, where minute balls of gold are used to create patterns on gold sheets; fusion welding, in which organic glue and acetate copper are used to adhere gold granules onto surfaces upon which oxygen-free flame is applied; chasing, in which designs are inscribed on the surface; repoussé, in which the designs are hammered out from the back; and casting, in which the lost-wax method is employed to make solid components for gold chains, necklaces, rings, and earrings. The gold collection of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (Central Bank of the Philippines) possesses numerous examples made with these techniques.

 

Trappings of Power

As far back as the Neolithic period (4000/3000-500 BCE), charismatic chieftains emerged from pools of “valiants” or men of prowess. These leaders, only sometimes inheriting their offices, knew how to gather followers by making ostensive displays of influence, wearing sumptuous jewelry, and dressing in resplendent clothing. They periodically sponsored elaborate feasts that fed and entertained multitudes, thus reinforcing their status and authority. After contact with the great traditions of India and China, indigenous leaders and their small states began taking the trappings of the greater ones. The Song Shi or Song dynasty history notes that Butuan and Samal kings began co-opting foreign emblems of authority at the start of the 11th century. Rulers coveted ceremonial flags and military titles that the Chinese court bestowed on tributary states and, as late as the 16th century, high-ranking persons wore the upavita (yajnopavita or sacred thread), a cord slung over one shoulder by all those twice-born (having undergone both physical and spiritual births), a tradition reserved for members of the higher castes of Brahmins, Kshatriyas, and Vaishyas in India. A gold upavita of significant weight and proportion is in the collection of the Ayala Museum.

 

Early Polities

Chinese and Arab chronicles record the rise of power centers in the 10th and 11th centuries, including P’u-tuan/Butuan and Ma-I, and in the 15th and 16th centuries, including Manila, Maguindanao, Sulu, and Cebu. These chieftainships held sway over shifting alliances with second-tier power centers. Chieftains wore gold regalia to reinforce their legitimacy and many used gold for adornment, marriage, burials, and other rituals. They exchanged pottery for sea and forest products from second-tier power centers, which in turn paid for Chinese, Thai, Vietnamese, and Khmer stoneware and porcelains—goods that enhanced their status during “feasts of merit.”

One of the largest yields of archaeological gold has come from Butuan, Agusan del Norte, northeastern Mindanao. As early as 320 CE and on vessels called balanghai constructed for long-distance travel, Butuanon navigated not only the Agusan River and marshlands but also the sea. Like others plying the South China Sea, they used wooden planks for their hulls with edges pegged down side by side, as seen in the balanghai (320 CE). The location of their settlements shifted with changes to local shorelines and riverbanks. They depended on metal, pottery, forest produce, and foreign trade. Gold was bountiful and goldsmithing was practiced vigorously, alongside bronze- and ironworking. Butuan’s population appears to have expanded and contracted between the 10th and 13th centuries. As evidenced by high-fired Asian trade ware, other urban centers took part in the same maritime networks, including Surigao, also in northeastern Mindanao; Batangas and Mindoro in southern Luzon; and Samar in eastern Visayas.

 

Indian Influence

After Sanskrit came into the Philippine languages between 900 CE and 1000 CE, gold began to be worked on with increasing sophistication. Indic influence on Philippine religious, intellectual, and cultural life may be seen in words like bathala (god), diwata (deity), budhi (conscience), and bhasa (language), some of the 150 Indic words that entered the Philippine languages. Studies show that these terms came through non-Sanskrit speakers, such as Filipino travelers and other Southeast Asian islanders, possibly from the Hinduized Sri-Vijaya empire whose base was in Sumatra (700-1377 CE). As important carriers of Indic influence in Southeast Asia, these non-Sanskrit speakers had brief but profound links with Tagalog speakers and had made independent contact through trade at separate periods of history with the people of Sulu and the Visayas.

 

While these may not have been found in archaeological contexts, gold figures in the Ayala Museum collection—the garuda, nagaraja, and kinnari—have nonetheless broached the possibility of a local Hindu-Buddhist iconography developing in the Philippines. Other evidence, possibly from the Proto-historic period (1000-1300 CE), found in the past 30 years include an Ivory Seal that reads “But-wan” in ancient Javanese or early Kawi script (undated) at the National Museum and a Tantric inscription on a strip of gold found in Butuan in a private collection. Pieces established early on in the country’s archaeological record are the Golden Image of Tara, consort of a Bodhisattva of Mahayana or Vajrayana/Tantric Buddhism (late 13th to early 14th century), which a Manobo woman found in Esperanza, Agusan del Sur, now in the Field Museum in Chicago; the Avalokitesvara-Padmapani Clay Medallion from Calatagan, Batangas (12th-13th century), in the National Museum of the Philippines; the Bronze Lokesvara Statue from Cebu (12th-13th century), lost during World War II; and the Golden Garuda Pendant from Brooks Point, Palawan (early 14th century), stolen from the National Museum in 1983.

 

Rise and Fall of Butuan

Understanding early links with Hindu-Buddhist and Muslim traditions perforce starts with the rise and fall of ancient Butuan. Over the span of four years (1003-1007 CE), Chinese chroniclers note that the Butuan ruler Kiling (Qi-ling) sent missions requesting to pay tribute directly to China, thereby bypassing Champa in the exchange of tribute gifts. Kiling was denied, but other Butuan missions followed. In 1011, a Butuan ruler with the Indianized name Sri Bata Shaji succeeded in having Butuan recognized as a tributary state after having sent the Chinese court a memorial engraved on a gold tablet, along with an impressive stock of cloves from the Moluccas. “To honor a distant land,” the Chinese awarded the Butuan representative with a military title, armor, ceremonial flags, and pennons (flags with tapering tails). After 1300, Muslim influence in Southeast Asia grew. Islamized Brunei, Sulu, western Mindanao, and southern Luzon challenged Indianized Butuan and, not long after, Brunei claimed Butuan as a dependency. When the Spaniards arrived in 1521, Butuan was past its zenith. While Butuanons continued to extract gold, they did so only for personal use, and because the early Spanish colonizers confiscated what gold they found, the locals eventually discontinued its sourcing, processing, and production.

 

International Trade during Protohistory

Since the Proto-historic period (900-1500 CE), seamanship was an important feature of trade and population movements. Chinese junks came with ironware, brassware, tin, porcelain, stoneware, unglazed pottery, silk threads, sarsaparilla (chinaroot), incense, and glass beads. Bornean parao sailed in with camphor, fine-woven mats, sago cakes, perfumes, drugs, Bornean red cloth, Indian chintz, and Javanese batik. The Visayas traded with wax, civet musk, cinnamon, dyewood and aromatic hardwood, red resin, and red ants (for Chinese ink), and Sulu provided pearls, corals, and tortoise shell. Butuan supplied its staple trade of gold, wax, and slaves; and other sites in Mindanao sent deerskin, antlers, and caged civet cats to Japan.

In 1565, Basque Spanish navigator Miguel Lopez de Legazpi arrived in the Visayas to colonize the Philippines. His chronicler recorded an interview with the chief pilot of a captured parao owned by a Portuguese and loaded with cargo funded by the sultan of Brunei. The “Moro” informed the general that their two junks from Luzon were in Butuan bartering for gold, wax, and slaves and that the captured parao traded with goods similar to those carried by the Borneans: all from China. While the locals considered the Bornean and Luzon boats as Chinese junks, he added, the actual junks from China were too large to come close to the islands (Anon. 1565, 467).

In fact, large Chinese junks delivered goods to Manila and Borneo and smaller Malay-operated boats redistributed goods to the Visayas in exchange for gold and slaves. What is gleaned from these early chronicles is that highly developed polities in the archipelago enjoying a thriving international trade were in place long before the Europeans first mentioned the Philippines as people of Luçoes in Suma Oriental, 1513, and that a system of interregional cooperation was in practice well before explorer Ferdinand Magellan first landed in these islands in 1521.   Written by Purissima Benitez-Johannot

article.value: Gold was abundant in the Philippines, and ancient burial customs favored adornments made from this precious metal. Worked gold was found in various parts of the archipelago: central Luzon (Novaliches, Rizal, Laguna) yielded piloncitos (tiny gold coins used by Filipinos for barter during pre-Hispanic times) similar to those found in Sri Vijayan sites (700-1377 CE); northwestern Luzon (Bolinao in Pangasinan) and southern Luzon (Sorsogon) yielded gold beads and ornaments; and the islands of Mindoro, Palawan, Cebu, Panay, and Bohol in the central Philippines yielded a variety of repoussé jewelry, beads, dental inlay, and gold sheet face covers, such as the Oton death mask (late 1500s to early 1600s). So far, excavated sites in Butuan and Surigao in northeastern Mindanao and Samar in eastern Visayas have produced the widest range and largest quantities of gold ornaments. These centers of gold production have yielded pieces unrivaled in Island Southeast Asia, evidencing sophisticated techniques like granulation, where minute balls of gold are used to create patterns on gold sheets; fusion welding, in which organic glue and acetate copper are used to adhere gold granules onto surfaces upon which oxygen-free flame is applied; chasing, in which designs are inscribed on the surface; repoussé, in which the designs are hammered out from the back; and casting, in which the lost-wax method is employed to make solid components for gold chains, necklaces, rings, and earrings. The gold collection of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (Central Bank of the Philippines) possesses numerous examples made with these techniques.
Trappings of Power

As far back as the Neolithic period (4000/3000-500 BCE), charismatic chieftains emerged from pools of “valiants” or men of prowess. These leaders, only sometimes inheriting their offices, knew how to gather followers by making ostensive displays of influence, wearing sumptuous jewelry, and dressing in resplendent clothing. They periodically sponsored elaborate feasts that fed and entertained multitudes, thus reinforcing their status and authority. After contact with the great traditions of India and China, indigenous leaders and their small states began taking the trappings of the greater ones. The Song Shi or Song dynasty history notes that Butuan and Samal kings began co-opting foreign emblems of authority at the start of the 11th century. Rulers coveted ceremonial flags and military titles that the Chinese court bestowed on tributary states and, as late as the 16th century, high-ranking persons wore the upavita (yajnopavita or sacred thread), a cord slung over one shoulder by all those twice-born (having undergone both physical and spiritual births), a tradition reserved for members of the higher castes of Brahmins, Kshatriyas, and Vaishyas in India. A gold upavita of significant weight and proportion is in the collection of the Ayala Museum.
Early Polities

Chinese and Arab chronicles record the rise of power centers in the 10th and 11th centuries, including P’u-tuan/Butuan and Ma-I, and in the 15th and 16th centuries, including Manila, Maguindanao, Sulu, and Cebu. These chieftainships held sway over shifting alliances with second-tier power centers. Chieftains wore gold regalia to reinforce their legitimacy and many used gold for adornment, marriage, burials, and other rituals. They exchanged pottery for sea and forest products from second-tier power centers, which in turn paid for Chinese, Thai, Vietnamese, and Khmer stoneware and porcelains—goods that enhanced their status during “feasts of merit.”

One of the largest yields of archaeological gold has come from Butuan, Agusan del Norte, northeastern Mindanao. As early as 320 CE and on vessels called balanghai constructed for long-distance travel, Butuanon navigated not only the Agusan River and marshlands but also the sea. Like others plying the South China Sea, they used wooden planks for their hulls with edges pegged down side by side, as seen in the balanghai (320 CE). The location of their settlements shifted with changes to local shorelines and riverbanks. They depended on metal, pottery, forest produce, and foreign trade. Gold was bountiful and goldsmithing was practiced vigorously, alongside bronze- and ironworking. Butuan’s population appears to have expanded and contracted between the 10th and 13th centuries. As evidenced by high-fired Asian trade ware, other urban centers took part in the same maritime networks, including Surigao, also in northeastern Mindanao; Batangas and Mindoro in southern Luzon; and Samar in eastern Visayas.
Indian Influence

After Sanskrit came into the Philippine languages between 900 CE and 1000 CE, gold began to be worked on with increasing sophistication. Indic influence on Philippine religious, intellectual, and cultural life may be seen in words like bathala (god), diwata (deity), budhi (conscience), and bhasa (language), some of the 150 Indic words that entered the Philippine languages. Studies show that these terms came through non-Sanskrit speakers, such as Filipino travelers and other Southeast Asian islanders, possibly from the Hinduized Sri-Vijaya empire whose base was in Sumatra (700-1377 CE). As important carriers of Indic influence in Southeast Asia, these non-Sanskrit speakers had brief but profound links with Tagalog speakers and had made independent contact through trade at separate periods of history with the people of Sulu and the Visayas.

article.value: While these may not have been found in archaeological contexts, gold figures in the Ayala Museum collection—the garuda, nagaraja, and kinnari—have nonetheless broached the possibility of a local Hindu-Buddhist iconography developing in the Philippines. Other evidence, possibly from the Proto-historic period (1000-1300 CE), found in the past 30 years include an Ivory Seal that reads “But-wan” in ancient Javanese or early Kawi script (undated) at the National Museum and a Tantric inscription on a strip of gold found in Butuan in a private collection. Pieces established early on in the country’s archaeological record are the Golden Image of Tara, consort of a Bodhisattva of Mahayana or Vajrayana/Tantric Buddhism (late 13th to early 14th century), which a Manobo woman found in Esperanza, Agusan del Sur, now in the Field Museum in Chicago; the Avalokitesvara-Padmapani Clay Medallion from Calatagan, Batangas (12th-13th century), in the National Museum of the Philippines; the Bronze Lokesvara Statue from Cebu (12th-13th century), lost during World War II; and the Golden Garuda Pendant from Brooks Point, Palawan (early 14th century), stolen from the National Museum in 1983.
Rise and Fall of Butuan

Understanding early links with Hindu-Buddhist and Muslim traditions perforce starts with the rise and fall of ancient Butuan. Over the span of four years (1003-1007 CE), Chinese chroniclers note that the Butuan ruler Kiling (Qi-ling) sent missions requesting to pay tribute directly to China, thereby bypassing Champa in the exchange of tribute gifts. Kiling was denied, but other Butuan missions followed. In 1011, a Butuan ruler with the Indianized name Sri Bata Shaji succeeded in having Butuan recognized as a tributary state after having sent the Chinese court a memorial engraved on a gold tablet, along with an impressive stock of cloves from the Moluccas. “To honor a distant land,” the Chinese awarded the Butuan representative with a military title, armor, ceremonial flags, and pennons (flags with tapering tails). After 1300, Muslim influence in Southeast Asia grew. Islamized Brunei, Sulu, western Mindanao, and southern Luzon challenged Indianized Butuan and, not long after, Brunei claimed Butuan as a dependency. When the Spaniards arrived in 1521, Butuan was past its zenith. While Butuanons continued to extract gold, they did so only for personal use, and because the early Spanish colonizers confiscated what gold they found, the locals eventually discontinued its sourcing, processing, and production.
International Trade during Protohistory

Since the Proto-historic period (900-1500 CE), seamanship was an important feature of trade and population movements. Chinese junks came with ironware, brassware, tin, porcelain, stoneware, unglazed pottery, silk threads, sarsaparilla (chinaroot), incense, and glass beads. Bornean parao sailed in with camphor, fine-woven mats, sago cakes, perfumes, drugs, Bornean red cloth, Indian chintz, and Javanese batik. The Visayas traded with wax, civet musk, cinnamon, dyewood and aromatic hardwood, red resin, and red ants (for Chinese ink), and Sulu provided pearls, corals, and tortoise shell. Butuan supplied its staple trade of gold, wax, and slaves; and other sites in Mindanao sent deerskin, antlers, and caged civet cats to Japan.

In 1565, Basque Spanish navigator Miguel Lopez de Legazpi arrived in the Visayas to colonize the Philippines. His chronicler recorded an interview with the chief pilot of a captured parao owned by a Portuguese and loaded with cargo funded by the sultan of Brunei. The “Moro” informed the general that their two junks from Luzon were in Butuan bartering for gold, wax, and slaves and that the captured parao traded with goods similar to those carried by the Borneans: all from China. While the locals considered the Bornean and Luzon boats as Chinese junks, he added, the actual junks from China were too large to come close to the islands (Anon. 1565, 467).

In fact, large Chinese junks delivered goods to Manila and Borneo and smaller Malay-operated boats redistributed goods to the Visayas in exchange for gold and slaves. What is gleaned from these early chronicles is that highly developed polities in the archipelago enjoying a thriving international trade were in place long before the Europeans first mentioned the Philippines as people of Luçoes in Suma Oriental, 1513, and that a system of interregional cooperation was in practice well before explorer Ferdinand Magellan first landed in these islands in 1521.
