Sections

Historical Background
The Visual Arts during Martial Law
Related Content
Sources

 

Historical Background

When Ferdinand Marcos began his first term as president of the Philippines in 1965, there was heightened political awareness that raised issues of national importance: the effect on the economy of the multinational corporations, the United States (US) military bases, corruption in government, and gross social inequalities. Under Marcos, the peso was devaluated upon instructions from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), which represents the capitalist bloc of countries led by the United States. Peso devaluation, along with cheap labor, assured big profits for foreign investments, thereby attracting multinational corporations which proved disadvantageous to the majority of working masses. Cronyism and corruption in government became rampant. It was estimated that 50 percent of the nation’s wealth were in the hands of 5 percent of the population and that this 5 percent consisted of landlords and compradors, agents of foreign monopoly capital (Guillermo 2001).

The atmosphere was rife with political strife and growing unrest largely from a studentry backed and led by militant organizations, among them the Student Cultural Association of the University of the Philippines (SCAUP), founded by Jose Ma. Sison in 1961, and the Kabataang Makabayan (Nationalist Youth) or KM, also founded by Sison in 1964 (Guillermo 2001). Informed by the doctrines of Karl Marx, Vladimir Lenin, and Mao Tse-tung, these groups were mobilized in the larger context of an international radicalized student movement in the late 1960s and 1970s (Flores 2013, 2). In the Philippines, this movement’s foremost ideologue was Sison, who also founded the Communist Party of the Philippines in 1968 and its military arm, the New People’s Army (NPA), in 1969. In the same year, Marcos became the first Philippine president to be reelected. In 1973, the National Democratic Front was founded. It was a broad coalition of mass organizations of workers, urban poor, youth, professionals, nuns and priests, who played an expanding role in the revolutionary movement.

Imposition of Martial Law. Mass actions escalated during Marcos’s second term, the most notable of which is known as the First Quarter Storm from January to March of 1970. In 1971, just as Marcos was convening the Constitutional Convention to amend the Constitution according to his own political and economic interests, the oil price hike of two centavos triggered a big rally that turned into a riot. This was accompanied by a weeklong general strike, with transportation coming to a standstill and all schools closed. The streets were filled with indignation rallies and during Marcos’s State of the Nation Address, the Kabataang Makabayan hurled a coffin before his face.

The ensuing chaos became a justification for the declaration of martial law on 21 Sep 1972 through Proclamation 1081. The declaration enabled Marcos to consolidate his executive and legislative powers, and enabled him to stay in office practically for life, long after the constitutionally mandated eight-year limit. He suspended the Constitution and dissolved Congress in a bid to dismantle what to him was at the root of the nation’s problems—the oligarchy.

During the initial years of martial law, a semblance of economic progress was projected by investing in structures, such as bridges, highways, and seaports, aimed at expanding commerce and trade. New jobs were created in urban and rural areas, but only the very few benefited from such developments. Favors were dispensed to relatives and friends, which created a culture of patronage and indebtedness. The oligarchy that Marcos sought to break was replaced by technocrats and cronies. Amidst uneven modernization and poor economic growth, civil liberties—the cornerstones of modern democracy—were violated. Within the frame of what he termed “constitutional authoritarianism,” Marcos built a legal and military infrastructure consisting of proclamations, executive orders, and counterinsurgency operations carried out in the countryside, in the urban and rural areas, in the form of arrests, illegal detentions to “salvagings” of suspected NPAs, and massacres of peasants (Guillermo 2001, 14).

The New Society and National Identity. From the eve of the declaration of martial law in the 1970s to the beginning of the regime’s decline in the 1980s, there prevailed a climate of fear and a “metaphysical unrest” (as described by critic Armando Manalo) felt by a restive populace losing faith and confidence in its leaders. Even if propped up by superior force, Marcos’s hold on power was besieged with a crisis of legitimacy. He had to convince the populace about the rightness of his rule and his right to that rule. This he strove to accomplish, not by force but a soft approach aimed at winning the hearts and minds of the populace. He built and projected his image as a brilliant, reliable paternal figure who, together with Imelda as mother of the nation, would lead the country toward cultural rebirth. He stated that the Philippines was suffering from an “identity crisis” and he considered it his mission to lead in restoring racial pride grounded on a common origin predating colonial conquest—the Great Malayan culture—and a common destiny, the New Society. Writing in a four-volume tome titled Tadhana (Destiny), 1976, he put forward his view of a people who, after participating in “man’s universal evolution,” would go through a “particularization process that would over the centuries produce a racial identity” that would later develop into a unique and distinct nation. Marching as a New Society, this regenerated nation joins other nations of the free world in the path toward modernity and progress.

This fusion of rebirth of a long-lost civilization, on the one hand, and aspiration to modernization and development, on the other, was propagated and implemented through an art and culture program that combined the fine arts, architecture, interior design, tourism, convention city building (hotels, theaters, coliseums), engineering, urban planning, health, among many others. Carried out in a scale, scope, and magnitude never seen before and since in the Philippines, the official art program was made possible through a controlled media, a tourism that advertised the humane and cosmopolitan face of the Philippines abroad, a national beautification program led by First Lady Imelda Marcos, who was also appointed as minister of human settlements and governor of Metro Manila (Baluyut 2012). She spearheaded the construction of hotels, hospitals, schools, housing projects, and even an efficient transport system—for example, the Love Bus that linked commercial districts in Cubao and Baclaran via Makati (Herrera 1998).

With this comprehensive cultural program in place, the Marcoses presided over the nation as monumental figures able to unite their “children” as loving parents with a love story and an ancestry both human and mythical. Ferdinand commissioned and wrote histories to project a dubious wartime heroism, and a genealogy that supposedly molded Marcos’s character as a reformer and political genius, deserving of dynastic rule. Marcos and his wife styled themselves as monarchs through portraits showing them bedecked with aristocratic sash, medals, swords, and crowns. Their portraits would portray them in an idealized style, garbed as royalty, and in Imelda’s case juxtaposed with Queen Nefertiti of ancient Egypt. They built structures that looked like palaces: Malacañang ti Amianan in the North and Imelda’s house in Tacloban patterned after the Palace of Versailles. They staged events worthy of royalty, such as the lavish wedding of their youngest daughter in Sarrat, Marcos’s hometown in Ilocos Norte.

Along the Marcos Highway, the Marcos Monument aka Marcos Bust, 1981, once sat as a concrete and visible manifestation of this magisterial image. Like a sentinel, it guarded the gateway leading to Baguio, the summer capital. Its form—colossal in scale—was a symptom of modernity; its content was archaic. Modern monuments celebrate groups or nations; ancient monuments focus on individuals, and their aristocratic or monarchic statuses and titles. The monument can be seen as a metaphor of Marcos’s body and his regime’s body politic, with a vein—the highway that bears his name—that connects north and south and a face made in his image, simultaneously benevolent and stern. The giant bust soared and surveyed its constituents with an unblinking and totalizing gaze that protected its domain and ensured its integrity as a New Society (Baluyut 1994). In 1989, the structure suffered damages by a blast reportedly done by the New People’s Army. It was subsequently destroyed in 2002 by bomb blasts from suspected treasure hunters of the Yamashita treasure.

Ferdinand and Imelda embellished this imperial image by tracing a mythical ancestry from precolonial society. In paintings and even on the doors of Malacañan, Marcos and Imelda are depicted as Malakas (Strong) and Maganda (Beautiful), the precolonial versions of the biblical Adam and Eve. Government hospitals, such as the Philippine Heart Center, became venues of mural paintings with themes celebrating folk traditions. At other times, the couple also appropriated the legend of Maria Makiling. For example, at the dedication ceremony of the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA) on 7 Apr 1976, the Marcoses “performed” their commitment to the arts by referencing the myth of the fabled mountain, on which the school was built. It supported a select group of talented young artists, who after going through a rigorous audition, were entitled to a full scholarship and board and lodging (Baluyut 1994). In her speech, Imelda offered PHSA to her husband, the “sensitive dreamer” who built the school she described as “the allegory of our creative passions,” a “metaphor of our dreams.” In his speech, Ferdinand likened Imelda to a sorceress able to turn “dreams into reality and reality into a dream”—practically a reincarnation of the generous, graceful, and beautiful goddess. School and mountain became the site of the magical translation of the local myth into a “national love story between a mortal (Ferdinand) and a goddess (Imelda), who sought to give birth to a New Society of artists” (Baluyut 1994, 50). The old is contemporized, myth crosses over to human reality, a mortal turns into a goddess—all expressed through the currency of love between superhumans, a love made indistinguishable from a public and national kind of love, love for country.

CCP as Shrine to High Art. As index of progress, refinement, radical experiment, national identity, and love for country, art was circulated through an intricate network of institutions that braided the threads of the premodern and vernacular, the modern and international. National pride was instilled by invoking the premodern through murals, folk festivals, and museums devoted to collecting and displaying ethnographic artifacts and natural specimens. Among these key sites was the National Museum, which was revitalized through constitutional amendments.

At the center of this arts and culture program was the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), the premier bureaucratic entity through which art acquisition, exhibition making, workshops, grants, and awards were implemented. It was created on 25 Jun 1966 through Executive Order 30 and inaugurated in 1969, the year Marcos was elected to his second term as Philippine president. The modernist-cantilevered building described as a cross between the vernacular bahay kubo (nipa hut) and art brut minimalism, was designed by Leandro Locsin, chief architect of Imelda. It stands like a shrine to High Art on land reclaimed from historic Manila Bay. Like the Marcos monument, this pantheon to art presides over and stands guard at the entrance of the CCP Complex, which consists of satellite structures with varying functions: the Folk Arts Theater, which became the venue of the first Miss Universe Pageant in the Philippines in 1974; the state-of-the-art Philippine International Convention Center, which housed the 1976 IMF–World Bank Conference; the Tahanang Filipino or Coconut Palace, which was built in anticipation of a papal visit; and the Manila Film Center, which was built to host the Manila International Film Festival to ambitiously rival Cannes.

Pageantry, urban planning, design, and architecture were mobilized in the service of the New Society, its lineage and identity. A number of the buildings in the complex, for example, employed concrete blocklike forms indicative of the modern style, while some buildings integrated vernacular elements in conformity with the state’s thrust of reviving Filipino traditions. For example, the National Arts Center in the aforementioned PHSA campus in Mount Makiling, designed by Locsin, appropriated the style of vernacular houses like the Ifugao fale; while the Coconut Palace, designed by Architect Francisco Mañosa, utilized indigenous building materials and fashioned the roof to look like a salakot, the native hat worn by farmers to protect them from the elements in the fields.

Along with architecture, the Design Center of the Philippines (DCP), which was established in 1973, similarly crafted an aesthetic that encompassed the vernacular and the avant-garde. DCP came under the directorship of Arturo Luz, who developed buri, handmade paper, and other local materials for interior design. Located at the rear of the CCP main building, the DCP translated indigenous motifs into contemporary forms applicable to commercial and industrial design, packaging, and marketing of Philippine products.

The Marcos period propelled a building boom that aspired to build a City of Man, where everything that is true, good, and beautiful reigned supreme. Projecting a cosmopolitan image, the complex edged out a burgeoning urban population, which the City of Man concealed behind whitewashed fences. Imelda was working on a tight schedule while the complex was being constructed, and there were casualties. For example, the Film Center was built at such breakneck speed that midway through the construction, a structure collapsed, trapping hundreds of workers, who were buried under tons of quick-drying cement.

Amidst the pageantry was resistance and criticism. At the very heart of the regime, a number of artists caused disruptions within the very flagship of Imelda’s City of Man. In 1969, during the inauguration of the CCP, the pioneering avant-garde David Medalla staged a protest with the poet Jun Lansang and the visual artist Mars Galang. They unfurled banners that read: “We Want a Home, Not a Fascist Temple,” “A Bas La Mystification” (Down with Pretense), “Down with Philistines,” and “Re: Gun, Go Home.” The latter text was a pun on the name of then California governor Ronald Reagan who, along with his wife Nancy, was representing American president Richard Nixon for the inauguration. The Medalla-Lansang-Galang trio positioned themselves strategically at a spot along the balconies overlooking the main lobby, where the Marcos and Reagan entourage were expected to pass on their way to the Main Theater (now Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo). Alongside these strident banners were placards held aloft by supporters of the regime. Outside the CCP were students who had displayed their own banners protesting the “prostitution” of the arts, which, as the other banners stated, were poisoning the minds of the hungry and the downtrodden. Barely 200 m away from “the fabulous Imelda Center, a ghetto sprawls, where thousands of Filipinos are kept captives by misery and poverty,” according to Senator Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino Jr, who delivered the speech on the CCP funds in front of the Senate a few months before the inauguration. It is said that late that evening of the inauguration, a hearse was roaming the streets of Manila in search of Medalla (Flores 2007-10).

Another example of a disruptive work is that of Jose Bautista, a CCP Thirteen Artists awardee in 1972, who submitted a work that appeared in the Five Contemporary Sculptors exhibition at the Museum of Philippine Art (MOPA). His work drove Imelda to close the exhibition prematurely. Because the exhibition run coincided with an IMF convention, she did not want to expose the delegates to the squalor portrayed in the work.

CCP as Vanguard of the Avant-garde. Through the recommendation of Arturo Luz, Roberto Chabet, who exhibited in Luz Gallery in 1961, became the first curator of the CCP Museum, from 1967 to 1970. He was awarded a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation, enabling him to travel to the United States and Europe from 1967 to 1968 to observe museum practices abroad before CCP opened. At CCP, he initiated the Thirteen Artists Award, loosely patterned after the influential survey “Sixteen Americans” at the Museum of Modern Art, New York, and also in honor of the pioneering Thirteen Moderns in Philippine art history. Under his brief tenure, he established CCP as a prime venue for artistic experimentation and collaboration. His work achieved official recognition when he received the Republic Cultural Heritage Award for the visual arts in 1972 and the Gawad CCP para sa Sining in 2015.

The first recipients of the Thirteen Artists Award in 1970 were Raymundo Albano (who succeeded Chabet as CCP Museum curator), Angelito Antonio, Virgilio Aviado, Eduardo Castrillo, Benedicto Cabrera, Restituto Embuscado, Marciano Galang, Lamberto Hechanova, Jaime de Guzman, Noel Manalo, Ben Maramag, Manuel Rodriguez Jr, and Antonio Austria.

Chabet was by this time exhibiting works that were avowedly conceptual, emphasizing the idea behind his art rather than technique and form. Eventually calling himself a Fluxus artist, he did collages, drawings, sculptures, and installations using found objects. While he was instrumental to CCP’s early development and increasingly became an establishment figure, his art never lost its critical bite. For the group exhibition Objects, held at the CCP in 1973, Chabet tore up a copy of a coffee-table book on Philippine contemporary art and placed it in a trash bin. The work, titled Tearing into Pieces, was seen as a scandalous critique of the conventions of the art world. In her book The Struggle for Philippine Art (1974), collector, critic, and founder of the Art Association of the Philippines Purita Kalaw-Ledesma described the work as “anti-museum art.” After his brief stint as CCP director and curator, he taught at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts (1971-2002), where he mentored a new generation of innovative Filipino artists who have become established painters, sculptors, and multimedia artists.

Under Chabet and later Raymundo Albano, the CCP Museum opened its exhibition programming to works influenced by the Western avant-garde and conceptual tenets, pop art, happenings, environmental assemblages, new realism, performance art, and sound works (Gatbonton 1992, in Flores 2009). Experiments in art challenged the commoditization of art within the consumerist system of the art world and its markets at the very heart of the Marcos regime. On the other hand, the Chabet-Albano axis also went beyond the CCP white cube as they opened up nonwhite cube sites for art exhibitions and performance spaces—furnaces, offices, warehouses, clock towers, shop windows, kitchens, public halls, and hotels, among others. Alternatives to museums were seen, for example, in Gallery 7, Sanctuary, Gallery Indigo, and the short-lived Shop 6 in Cubao, and later in one of the stalls of the Kamalig arcade in Manila. This shifting to alternative venues was also accompanied by the development of emergent art writing platforms, including the Philippine Art Supplement (PAS) and the Review Cultural Forum.

Modern art purveyed by the tight Chabet-Luz axis catered to the intellectual and cultural elite. Albano’s curatorial stance was more populist. He initiated projects under the rubrics he termed as “developmental art” aimed at exposing art to a learning public. He characterized the period 1971-75 as the “exposure phase” in which advanced art—experimental in nature—were displayed in the galleries. Non-art materials, such as sand, junk, iron, lumber, and rocks, were commonly used for the artists’ development strategies. People were shocked, scared, delighted, and satisfied even though their preconceived notions of art did not agree with what they encountered. “Exhibitions,” he wrote, “should be alive, not church-like, quite high in festive ambience.” They should also be thematic, dealing with current visual interests, and should be “stimulating, controversial but not scandalous.” If Chabet heralded the modern, Albano ushered in the contemporary by investing the modern with the urgency of the now. To be contemporary, he wrote, is to deal with “virtually untested, unknown realms of evidences that would lead to further understanding of ourselves” (Albano 1981).

 

Under Albano’s directorship, CCP also reached out to regions outside Manila (Baguio, Los Baños, Cebu) and beyond (Fukuoka, Paris, Southeast Asia), initiated art workshops and outreach programs through community involvement, and published reviews and other essays on art through PAS. Albano argued that although some experimental forms seemed wholly foreign, he invoked the practice of adorning ephemeral and familiar objects as in fiestas, which shared processes and features with installation art. An early example of installation art is Junyee’s Wood Things, 1981, made of kapok or cotton pods, installed on the walls and floor of the CCP’s white cube spaces to make these look like crawlers encroaching on the museum space.

Art curator Ma. Victoria Herrera, in her assessment of the institutional network of the Marcos years, writes that the new art introduced by the CCP and its satellites “may have promoted freedom for the artists but was geared to a limited and specialized public. The wider public then did not have the proper training through education to understand the ‘new’ art. Yet the modernism promoted by the CCP continued because it had the state’s support … the government was actually playing safe in the arts it was supporting. The MOPA programs supported art that was commercially viable while the CCP Museum promoted artistic expressions that could not be accommodated by the gallery system and the art market” (Herrera 1998).

Soon after the collapse of the Marcos administration in 1986, the MOPA was closed and the CCP would be beset with legal, logistic, and fiscal problems—a testament to the fact that while support to the arts was substantial during the Marcos period, the structures it provided, along with the reclaimed land the CCP stands on, are shaky and vulnerable.

 

State Patronage and the Art Market. Pioneering avant-garde David Medalla characterized Philippine art during this period as “nerve-racking fragmentation” (in Flores 2007-10). For artist Raymundo Albano, Philippine art “went into the crossroads,” speaking from his experience as CCP administrator-director from 1970 to 1985, prior to the declaration of martial law until the eve of the regime’s overthrow (Albano 1981). At the crossroads, the early moderns, who were already established artists in the 1960s, became fully entrenched in the canon of Philippine art when they were proclaimed National Artists through the CCP. While the conservatives are represented by Fernando Amorsolo, the first National Artist for visual arts who was posthumously awarded in 1972, and Guillermo Tolentino, awarded in 1973, the roster of National Artists for the visual arts are dominated by the moderns. Victorio Edades and Carlos “Botong” Francisco, two of the pioneering members of the Triumvirate of the prewar period, were proclaimed National Artists in 1976 and 1973, respectively. Along with Galo Ocampo, they formed a loose group called the Thirteen Moderns, which also included H.R. Ocampo, Vicente Manansala, Cesar Legaspi, Diosdado Lorenzo, Demetrio Diego, Jose Pardo, Bonifacio Cristobal, Arsenio Capili, Ricarte Puruganan, and Anita Magsaysay-Ho. H.R. Ocampo, proclaimed National Artist in 1991, along with Manansala, who was proclaimed National Artist in 1981, and Legaspi, proclaimed National Artist in 1990, led the formation of the group Neo-Realists, which assumed a more dynamic role in challenging the rural-pastoral style of the Amorsolo School. The group also included Romeo Tabuena, Victor Oteyza, Ramon Estella, Nena Saguil, Edades, and Francisco (Benesa 2015).

Investing heavily in art, the state took the lead in collecting both Western and local art, and institutionalized a protege system that geared young artists toward Western traditions through the Philippine High School for the Arts, a CCP satellite institution located in Mount Makiling. State patronage stimulated the art market. Art became big business. Architects, interior designers, and artists collaborated to their mutual benefit. The moderns, some of whom were later canonized as National Artists, were among those who benefited from this thriving and expanding collectors’ base. Edades was doing portraits; H.R. Ocampo had shed his social themes of the 1950s and was doing abstracts, such as Genesis, 1969, later executed as tapestry for the CCP Main Theater.

With the CCP as state flagship institution, modernism was circulated through a complicated but tight network of institutions, presided over by an elite clique of tastemakers, leaders, and movers. One of the key figures was Luz, who occupied several roles as artist, curator, and administrator in the Marcos machinery. He worked in tandem with artist and intellectual Fernando Zobel, who profoundly influenced Philippine art appreciation and criticism through his lectures on art at Ateneo de Manila. Ateneo Art Gallery, the first institution of modern art in the Philippines, benefited from Zobel’s bequest. Luz exhibited in the gallery, and a 10-year retrospective of his works, curated by Ateneo professor and art critic Emmanuel Torres, was held in 1966, the same year Luz received the Republic Heritage Award. Torres likewise wrote a book on his drawings and conceptualized an exhibition of Philippine art, running the length from the 19th-century master Juan Luna to Luz, underlining his benchmark status. Zobel also had a hand in the establishment of the Ayala Museum, founded on the heels of the Ateneo Art Gallery, Luz Gallery, and Lopez Memorial Museum. Ayala Museum opened on Herran St in 1967 and moved to Makati in 1974 in a building designed by pianist and theater artist Locsin, chief architect of Imelda and the Ayalas. Fernando Zobel’s cousin, Jaime Zobel de Ayala, the industrialist and business tycoon whose family practically owns the entire financial district of Makati, served as the first executive director and president of the CCP (Flores 2009).

Educated abroad, Zobel and Luz represented a new breed of artists in the 1950s who were influenced by Western art styles and explored “painting for painting’s sake” (Benesa 2015). Later, another painter of the same orientation and spirit also came back from studies abroad—Constancio Bernardo, who is described as a “disciple of Albers and his optico-geometric colorism” (Benesa 2015).

 

Other names that pivoted around Luz and Zobel were to become very visible during the Marcos years, among them Cenon Rivera, J.Elizalde Navarro, Federico Aguilar Alcuaz (National Artist, 2009), Joan Edades, Ang Kiukok (National Artist, 2001), Jess Ayco, Zny Laygo, Mauro Malang Santos, Hugo Yonzon, Oscar Zalameda, and Juvenal Sanso. The majority gravitated this time to a new showplace, according to Benesa: the Luz Gallery, which assumed the functions of the Philippine Art Gallery (PAG), which was then starting to lose its vitality and viability.

In 1977, Imelda appointed Luz to head the Museum of Philippine Art, formerly named Contemporary Art Museum of the Philippines, with Raymundo Albano at its helm. The MOPA, which operated through the CCP but was curatorially independent of it, also presented important retrospectives of groundbreaking modernists, many of whom would be proclaimed National Artists. Funded by the CCP, MOPA’s function was to promote national art internationally. Under a single director, MOPA and Luz Gallery became intricately connected. While MOPA assumed functions as a museum that acquired and housed a permanent collection, it was also selling art, a function more associated with galleries.

Aside from heading the MOPA, Luz was also at the helm of the Metropolitan Museum of Manila or the MET, another Imelda brainchild located a few meters away from the CCP Complex. Having opened in 1977 with loans from the Brooklyn Museum and other galleries in the United States, the MET was also internationalist in orientation. Through the years, it hosted exhibitions by known modern masters, among them Paul Klee and Joseph Beuys, as well as Byzantine icons and Yugoslav naif paintings.

Modern Art and Imagining the Nation. The Marcoses’s aggressive construction of a national identity through art may be traced to the long history of art and theme of nationalism explored by the modernists. In the 1950s, the early modernists portrayed the plight of industrial and urban workers amidst the debate between “proletarian art” and “art for art’s sake,” a debate that was as intense as that between the conservatives and moderns. H.R. Ocampo, a leading figure of the group called the Neo-Realists, painted the social inequalities and the oppression of industrial workers. One of his paintings showed the worker as Christ crucified among chimneys spewing forth pollution; another, The Contrast, 1940, showed a slum dweller in a hovel against a background of high-rise buildings while partaking of a humble repast. Manansala’s Madonna of the Slums, 1950, can also be considered an example of similar Neo-Realist sentiments, while Cesar Legaspi’s Gadgets, 1949, took up the theme of people turning into machines.

The issue of national identity bedeviled these early moderns, who developed an idiom that was at once modernist—that is, distinct from the Amorsolo school—and “Filipino,” however the term is defined. One group of artists placed much importance on historical research for defining national identity. An example is Carlos Francisco, the Angono-based artist who also worked in popular forms such as the comics, scenographic paintings for the theater, and costume design for the cinema. His knowledge of Philippine history enriched his murals depicting the history of Manila for the Bulwagang Katipunan (Katipunan Hall) at the Manila City Hall and his series on the history of medicine at the Philippine General Hospital. He made a lasting contribution to Philippine genre in paintings that reflected the life of the peasants and fisherfolk of the Laguna and Rizal lakeshore towns. To this sense of identity, he added the dimension of the people’s historical experience from precolonial times, as well as that of the ethnic and folk expressions in the national culture (Guillermo 1997).

Along the same line, another artist, Galo Ocampo, sought to indigenize Philippine religious imagery that had hitherto been of a Caucasian mold, a quality that subtly perpetuated colonial inferiority. His well-known painting that exemplifies the indigenization of religious imagery is the Brown Madonna, 1938. He also conveyed his strong reaction to the war through religious images of Christ’s passion as interpreted in Philippine folk religious customs, particularly in the image of the flagellant.

In the mid-1960s, a new generation of young painters matured as heirs to the progressive elements of the postwar period, especially the Neo-Realists. The poet, essayist, and foremost critic of the period, Leonidas Benesa, observed that this new generation “divides itself into two groupings, but with no real discernible organization or leadership. The first cluster consists of Roberto Chabet, Angelito Antonio, Florencio Concepcion, Charito Bitanga, Antonio Austria, David Aquino, Norma Belleza, Antonio Chan, William Chua, Veronica Lim, Leonardo Pacunayen, Angelito David, Antonio Hidalgo, Noel Manalo, and Manuel Rodriguez Jr. The second cluster consists of Alfredo Liongoren, Kelvin Chung, Marciano Galang, Virgilio Aviado, Ben Maramag, Benedicto Cabrera, Edgar Doctor, Lucio Martinez, Efren Zaragoza, Raul Lebajo, Raul Isidro, Prudencio Lamarroza, Jaime de Guzman, and Lamberto Hechanova Jr (Benesa 2015).

With Marcos’s interest to centralize his power and claim legitimacy through culture, it is therefore not surprising that modern art and its adherents found favor with the state. The interest in art as the symbol of a homogenous nation was a direction effectively sustained in other republics in Asia, post-World War II. In the hands of the dictatorship, this meant on the one hand a strong cultural policy aligned with economic development, and the suppression of dissident voices in the other. The fact that the idea of a nation can have permutations in terms of social class, ethnicity, and gender will find adherents in artists who fought martial law.

 

The Visual Arts during Martial Law

The issue of nation, national identity, and nationalism were major areas of concern that were interpreted in several ways, at times intersecting and oftentimes colliding. These concepts are politically diffuse, and they took many forms (Guillermo 1997). Nationalism was conceptualized and mobilized in this period by Marcos’s repressive regime to win popular consent and legitimization. Evoking tradition and race, Marcos’s nationalism was articulated as apolitical, totalizing, and homogenizing based on an unchanging essence of what it is to be Filipino. In opposition, there is the nationalism of the many unknown revolutionary artists, which is anti-imperialist and anti-neocolonial, and articulated within the class struggle.

During the period immediately preceding martial law (1965-69), three figures defined nationalism in the context of protest. Danilo Dalena, a top political cartoonist, satirized public figures led by Marcos and his cronies and the ubiquitous figure of Uncle Sam. Painter and student activist Jaime de Guzman worked on the theme of history, rather than contemporary reality, drawing inspiration from the 19th century, which for him was a heroic age of nationalism and revolution that reverberated into the present struggle. Printmaker and painter Benedicto Cabrera or BenCab similarly focused on the theme of national identity and anticolonial struggle, but in mediums and techniques that explored new expressive devices such as montage, multiple framing, and serial repetition. His Larawan series (ongoing from 1972) exemplifies these explorations. It linked the precolonial past and the postcolonial present through photographs. From a wide range of portraits of Filipino types and scenes—from mestiza women, petty politicians, soldiers marching, and a public execution—he created “montages, juxtaposing, cropping, multiplying and reversing them like playing cards in order to elicit meanings” (Guillermo in Flores 2013). The way he juxtaposed these scenes and characters illustrates a keen awareness of historical contradictions.

Dalena also painted canvases depicting faceless mobs as the dreary audience and decadent participants at horse races, jai alai, and sweepstakes betting lines, and religious processions. Dalena and de Guzman were expressionist, painterly, and dramatic, aiming for the epic sweep. Other expressionists included Ang Kiukok, whose apocalyptic landscapes mirrored the conflict and despair of the times, and Onib Olmedo, who explored the lower depths in haunting images of the dispossessed. Olmedo and Dalena came out strongly with faces imaged from the anonymous crowd. Ang, on the other hand, initially put off beholders with his distorted and angular crucifixions and his anguished skeletal figures.

Dalena, de Guzman, and BenCab were highly influential in shaping the course of protest art, although these influences on younger artists were not immediately apparent and recognized. Among those who were inspired by the historical allegories of de Guzman and BenCab were Orlando Castillo, former president of the Printmakers Association of the Philippines, and Renato Habulan. Both artists draw on 19th-century figures, both real and fictional. Sisa, the haunting fictional figure in Rizal’s novel, appears in the work of Habulan, and Bonifacio-like figures are motifs in Castillo’s work.

Dalena, Ang, and Olmedo represented a new generation who were active amidst the bustling art scene resulting from the state’s patronage of the art under martial law. Other notable names are Romulo Olazo, Antonio Austria, Angelito Antonio, Lino Severino, Mauro Malang Santos, Mario Parial, Angelito David, Rodolfo Ragodon, Jose Blanco, and Sofronio Y. Mendoza, among others. A number of art trends were also becoming discernible, such as the “vanishing scene” paintings, which sought to portray images of social transition, relics and vestiges of an earlier time, whether from the 19th century or the early American period (Guillermo 1997). This is seen in the tonal paintings of a more documentary and literal quality, such as those by Lino Severino who painted old houses in decay, or in the ink drawings of Antonio Doctor.

Folk genre of Botong Francisco’s tradition was carried on by lakeshore artists of Angono, Tanay, and Binangonan. These included painters such as Jose Blanco, Salvador Juban, Nemesio Miranda, and Vicente Reyes. There was likewise a trend of schooled artists consciously developing a “folk-naive” quality, portraying native subjects in a style derived from folk and children’s art. Among these were Antonio Austria, and to some extent Mario Parial (Guillermo 1997). Another subgroup is more popularly known as the Dimasalang Group, which promoted Impressionist styles. Among the group members were Sofronio Mendoza, Emilio Aguilar Cruz, Romulo Galicano, and Ibarra dela Rosa (Flores 1998).

Brenda Fajardo, educator, art administrator, community organizer, visual and theater artist, is largely identified with the indigenized tarot card, within which she frames historical and social events and issues. On the other hand, Norma Belleza is known for her genre paintings of ordinary people, rendered in her distinctive style combining the folk characteristics of highly saturated colors and the cubist rendering of stocky and hard-edged figures. Araceli Limcaco-Dans’s paintings reference needlework in her meticulously rendered Calado (heavy embroidery) series.

Printmaking in the Philippines became recognized as a contemporary art medium in the 1960s onward even if at one juncture was thought of as “dead.” This rejuvenation largely came through the efforts of Rod Paras-Perez and Manuel Rodriguez Sr. Rodriguez taught and formed departments of printmaking in the University of Santo Tomas and Philippine Women’s University (PWU), and brought with him the knowledge on printmaking he learned from studies in the United States. He opened the Contemporary Art Gallery for graphic artists, where he sold his students’ works. He helped organize the Philippine Association of Printmakers. The majority of the first young printmakers were taught by Rodriguez either in PWU or in his workshops at his gallery. Among these are Virgilio Aviado, Lucio Martinez, Lamberto Hechanova, Restituto Embuscado, Mario Parial, Adiel Arevalo, Petite Calaguas, Emet Valente, and Nonon Padilla as well as Rodriguez’s own sons Manuel Jr, Marcelino, and Ray Rodriguez. The Rodriguez workshops also attracted a number of women, whose contributions resonate till the present. They were Brenda Fajardo, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi, Ivi Avellana-Cosio, and Nelfa Querubin, among others. Printmaking changed the course of Rodriguez’s career, and his influence was felt mostly between the 1950s and the 1970s.

In sculpture, it was Napoleon Abueva, a student of Tolentino, who posed the modernist challenge to the Amorsolo and Tolentino schools through a variety of sculptural mediums—wood, stone, and metal—and styles ranging from figurative to abstract. Abueva has also developed a functional side to his sculpture in hand-carved benches, imaginative chairs, room dividers, and even a chariot. His works from the 1970s to the 1980s were commissioned sculptures for public spaces installed in the business district of Makati City. In 1976, he was declared National Artist.

In the early 1970s, Eduardo Castrillo emerged as a major sculptor, working in metal and a strong figurative style. His memorial park sculptures Pieta and The Last Supper are large-scale, featuring ungainly figures that evoke a sense of brokenness and rupture. He also produced sculptures of social themes, exemplified in metal reliefs such as the mural-size Boat Refugees. Solomon Saprid is similarly anticlassical. His Tikbalang, 1971, a half-man, half-horse image based on a Filipino folk belief in malevolent spirits, and his mother-and-child sculptures are dynamic, expressionistic, produced through a technique that welds strips of metal with a blowtorch resulting in an uneven and jagged surface.

At this time, Arturo Luz and Allan Cosio were doing works in basic geometric shapes in mediums of wood and stone, while Glenn Bautista did occasional sculptures in organic shapes. Abdulmari Imao, proclaimed National Artist in 2006, distinguished himself as a contemporary Muslim sculptor drawing inspiration from the okir tradition and from Islamic calligraphy.

In 1983, Julie Lluch produced a series of cacti, hearts, butts, and other organic shapes. Her acclaimed works have a highly personal approach and feminist signification. Her portraits in the 1980s were about women’s predicaments as mothers and wives exemplified in Philippine Gothic II and Picasso y Yo. Another important work is that of a full-length female nude appraising herself before a mirror signifying women’s awakening consciousness of herself as an independent entity. Agnes Arellano produced life-size sculptures aiming to provoke an immediate response from viewers. One of her works from the 1980s depicted a couple eternally cast, locked in an embrace that recalls the way her parents were found after the fire that burned down their home. From the ashes, Arellano built Pinaglabanan Galleries, which was a haven for experimental art shows outside the CCP.

Rey Paz Contreras’s Noise Barrage alluded to a popular form of protest during the transition period between Marcos and Aquino. This assemblage consisted of a standing sculpture with a xylophone-like arrangement of wooden bars on the lower level and hangings of an ethnic mask, an animal skull, and antique rifle and other symbols drawn from cultural minorities.

Sculptors worked in a variety of materials and techniques. J. Elizalde Navarro, Renato Rocha, Angelito Baldemor, Ros Arcilla, and Contreras worked in wood; Imao, Castrillo, Saprid, and Virginia Ty-Navarro in metal casting; Conrado Mercado and Honrado Fernandez used metal plates and rods; Jose Tence Ruiz, Edgar Doctor, J. Elizalde Navarro, and Lamberto Hechanova made mixed media assemblages.

Ildefonso Marcelo became famous for using adobe; Impy Pilapil and Ramon Orlina for glass; Lluch and Charlie Co for clay; Arellano, Peter de Guzman, and Dan Raralio for resin and plaster of paris. Francisco Verano and Roberto Feleo invented a sculptural medium made of fine wood shavings, acrylic polymer, and fiberglass. From his immediate environment in Los Baños, Junyee (Luis Yee Jr) sourced organic materials such as banana pulp, coconut shells, dried kapok pods, coconut twigs, and acacia bark, which he twined together to form mobiles and installations.

Artists who enjoyed Imelda’s patronage, such as Francisco and Jose Blanco, fit into the regime’s search for a premodern origin through the folk traditions portrayed in the artists’ landscape and genre paintings. At the same time, the non-objective art of Jose Joya, and the geometric abstractions of Arturo Luz, lent this nativist identity a cosmopolitan and international character. Non-objective art in the tradition of the New York School of Abstract Expressionism would be embodied in the canvases of Jose Joya and Lee Aguinaldo. Other artists who continued to work in the non-objective mode were Lao Lianben, Benjie Cabangis, Allan Cosio, Danilo Garcia, Romulo Olazo, August Albor, and Phyllis Zaballero.

One of the few women who explored the idiom of non-objective abstraction largely identified with Bernardo, Luz, and Joya was Nena Saguil, who lived in Paris since 1956 until her death in 1994. Going through a brief transition from figurative paintings into cubism in her early works in Paris, she largely used a network of lines to produce different geometric forms and shapes of textured canvases (Datuin 2002).

At the crossroads of Philippine Art, a plurality of ideas and expressions clashed, cohered, and collided in an infinity of layers impossible to plot in a tidy and linear mode. Modern art catered to the intellectual and cultural elite, while another type of art—from Mabini art to those by National Artists—catered to tourists and a vibrant collectors’ base. Popular forms, like comics and soap operas, became a refuge and escape for the majority; developmental art at the Shrine to High Art that was the CCP sought to educate, at times shocking as the art of the new. Some of those who enjoyed the support of the Marcos establishment—some emerging from the Philippine High School for the Arts, others from the CCP and its satellites, and other gatekeeper institutions—became its fiercest critics, but also its innovators who gave the most productive contributions to the art that was to follow after the Marcos years.

Protest and Revolutionary Art. The art historian Alice Guillermo (2001) coined the term “social realism” in the late 1980s to define the work of Kaisahan and artists associated with them. She links Philippine social realism with the socialist and realist movement in art espoused by artists like Gustave Courbet in the context of the intense republican struggles of 19th-century France. Philippine social realism, she writes, is similarly linked to the liberation movements in the Third World, but developed its own character arising out of its particular historical and cultural specificities. Social realism in the Philippines shares with its global counteparts its political orientation and the belief in art as an agent of social change.

Heir to the Neo-Realist tradition, the social realists of the 1970s grew out of a movement backed by militant organizations, among them the SCAUP and KM. When KM started to mobilize artists in their ranks, a group started to coalesce as early as 1969, and was officially formed in 1971. Called Nagkakaisang Progresibong Artista at Arkitekto (United Progressive Artists and Architects) or NPAA, the group produced art that aimed for greater visual impact and wider accessibility through popular forms such as posters, comics, and cartoons for people’s publications. This group set the precedent for a collective formed in 1976—Kaisahan (Solidarity), whose members initially included Pablo “Adi” Baens Santos, Edgar Talusan Fernandez, Renato Habulan, Antipas “Biboy” Delotavo, Papo de Asis, Albert Jimenez, and Jose Cuaresma. They were later joined by Al Manrique, Neil Doloricon, Jose Tence Ruiz, Orlando Castillo, Charles Funk, and the late graphic artist and photographer Vin Toledo who, with printmaker Orlando Castillo, served as political officer and ideologue. This group, according to Guillermo, was the first to be known as “social realist.” The members of the group who trained as painters—Castillo, Baens Santos, Habulan, and Fernandez—were already actively exhibiting before the formation of Kaisahan in 1976. They had minimal representation in Marcos’s cultural program and in fact was largely excluded from the CCP radar. The Kaisahan, after the NPAA, was the first cohesive organization of political artists who clearly affirmed their principles in a manifesto and subsequent texts.

At the height of martial law (1979) toward the beginning of the Marcos regime’s end (1983), the Kaisahan artists became very active. This is indicated by their artistic contributions that were later called protest and revolutionary art, a term that Guillermo subsequently used to accommodate a wider array of expressions and themes critical of the system, as these flourished during and even beyond the period. Using a variety of styles and media, the artists wove into the fabric of protest and revolutionary art a wide range of themes that captured the incongruities of the New Society. The themes are as follows: the Philippine Revolution of 1896, images of the Filipino, the three basic evils of society (feudalism, bureaucrat capitalism, and imperialism) and the struggles against these, the struggle of indigenous Filipinos, militarization and human rights violations, the threat to ecological balance, religious themes and theology of liberation, the plight of Filipino migrant workers, feminist themes, media censorship, the growth of the mass movement, and the vision of a new order (Guillermo 2001).

Delotavo’s Itak sa Puso ni Mang Juan (Knife in Juan’s Heart), 1978, portrays a stooped figure against an almost flat and stifling surface, where several contending forces are painted in a zone of unequal power relations: multinationals, on the one hand, and the exploited workers, on the other. A ubiquitous product of American capitalism overwhelms its consumers who are at the same time also its labor force. Advertising is so powerful and yet so oppressive that it is about to cut into human flesh through the serif of the letter “C” of the Coca-Cola logo, stopping short of piercing the heart, which continues to beat, albeit with disquietude and foreboding, seemingly warning of a coming storm.

Habulan is another artist who made incisive portraits of workers and peasants. In Dulo’t Dulo (Polarities), 1979, he brought out the great disparity existing between different social classes, in a montage of portraits consisting of images of the sakada (seasonal plantation workers) and the ilustrado (educated) landlords. His most outstanding work is the large-scale painting Kagampan (Fullness of Time) where several scores of workers and peasants carrying their working tools were massed together in several ascending rows occupying almost the entire visual field, as they confront the viewer in a show of strength and solidarity, their expressions and stances hinting at a smoldering anger and implying a challenge to the established order.

The social realists also introduced innovations and experimentations in their art, such as the use of wooden cutouts of peasants and workers, bark for painting, and photographic techniques using acrylic on canvas, as done by Edgar Talusan Fernandez, who also produced the first three-dimensional examples of protest art. Kinupot (Smothered) wrapped a group of figures in white cloth, with outlines of their hands and feet shown struggling against the taut sheet, conveying political repression. Doloricon used collage and wood panel montage; Tence Ruiz produced an assemblage of found objects and machine parts in his Jeepney series and box art.

Paris-based Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi, well-known for her prints, also uses silk, acrylic, and mixed media. From the Marcos years to the post-Aquino assassination years, she developed elegant social critiques by fusing religious, medieval, pop, contemporary, and folk images in her works. Self Images I, 1980, shows the Filipina in various guises as rural lass, hopeful professional graduate, Miss Body Beautiful, and peasant street sweeper—all rolled up and framed in a slot machine. Retablo (Altarpiece), 1982, unmasks the mythos of power disguised as holiness with shadowy military figures superimposed upon an altar of saints configured in a pinball machine.

Imelda Cajipe-Endaya is well-known for her large-scale collages made of sawali (woven-bamboo walls), crocheted curtains, denim pants, and brightly colored oilcloth. In these works, she painted images of women and their plight, starting from her own experience as a housewife. This proceeded from feminist impulse that matured into conscious advocacy after 1983, when she was among those who marched on the streets, founded and joined women’s groups, and became more directly social realist in her art.

Lani Maestro’s major works in the 1980s also dealt with the theme of political violence paying tribute to victims whose lives were lost to political killings, torture, and disappearances.

There were artists who drew vitality from actual interaction with people in the countryside and guerrilla zones in the heart of the armed struggle. Castillo’s paintings of his sojourn in the Cordilleras and Samar in early 1980 were never exhibited in a gallery. These depict situational images of NPA guerrillas in the field and in educational sessions, village doctors tending to the sick, and scenes of childbirth and death. Another social realist, Al Manrique presented a number of works after coming back from Davao in 1982. A 1983 painting, Ang Mabuhay sa Takot (To Live in Fear), alludes to hamleting or the relocation of peasants into instant villages so that the military could observe them more closely and isolate them from the guerrillas operating in their villages.

 

The martial law period also saw an unprecedented proliferation of popular art forms aimed at reaching out to non-museum audiences. Comics, murals, posters, drawings and illustrations for books, papier-mâché effigies, prints in etching, aquatint or rubbercut, photography, peryodikits (instant paintings on walls), masks, T-shirt printing, even pendants and greeting cards, among many others, were vehicles for political messages. Painters and graphic artists linked up with photographers to work on posters and other visual arts projects, especially during mass demonstrations and rallies. They also linked up with theater artists and musicians, thereby giving multimedia performances in auditoriums, on improvised stages, and on the streets, with visual artists exploring new roles in the other arts (Guillermo 2001).

While many continued to do paintings on oil and canvas, artists produced a number of popular forms. Tence Ruiz, Doloricon, Fernandez, and Jess Abrera became regular editorial cartoonists in newspapers and publications. Underground publications were enhanced with visual forms, such as Dare to Struggle / Dare to Win, three issues of which appeared from 1972 to 1973 addressed to cultural workers. The underground national cultural magazine Ulos had illustrations both by full-time underground movement artists and well-known social realists. Regional newspapers also contained illustrations for editorials, news features, and articles. Among these were Dangadang (Northwestern Luzon), Taliba ng Bayan (Manila-Rizal), Larab (Eastern Visayas), Baringkuas (Northeastern Luzon), and Pulang Silangan (East Central Luzon). Illustrations were also made for education manuals used in the cultural revolution, an example of which is Maikling Kurso tungkol sa Kilusang Magsasaka (Short Course on the Peasant Movement) published by the Komisyon sa Edukasyon at Propaganda (Education and Propaganda Commission) in Sep 1981.

Revolutionary artists gained a real firsthand knowledge of Philippine society and its conditions. Not satisfied with producing artworks, they shared their expertise in numerous workshops, conferences, art caravans, and tours that enabled greater circulation of artists all over the country. Soon, protest and revolutionary art began to flourish in the regions. Political organizations were formed in Davao and Bacolod. Because of these exchanges and greater mobility, a sense of a national identity and people’s culture took shape with substance and meaning that challenged Marcos’s vision of nation and national identity under the New Society.

Regional artists’ groups of various political persuasions were formed outside Manila. In Bacolod, one of the first artists’ groups was founded in 1980, the Pamilya Pintura. Its members included Nunelucio Alvarado, Charlie Co, Perry Argel, Jojo Regollo, Danny Dojillo, Norberto “Peewee” Roldan, Norberto Tarroja, Dennis Ascalon, Diokno Pasilan, and Boy Garovillo. By 1986, a number of artists from this group formed the Black Artists in Asia (BAA), a more radical organization. Members of this later group included Alvarado, Roldan, Co, Ascalon, and Lourdes Villanueva. The BAA spearheaded the Visayan Island Visual Art Exhibition and Conference and participated in the Baguio Arts Festival. Also in the 1980s in Mindanao, Tex Salvador founded the Artists Association of South Cotabato; the late Mike Martinez spearheaded the founding of the Art Association of Zamboanga (Datuin 1998).

It was also in the 1980s when women artists’ groups were established, such as Katipunan ng mga Kababaihan para sa Kalayaan (Organization of Women for Freedom or Kalayaan) and Kababaihan sa Sining at Bagong Sibol na Kamalayan (Women in Art and Emerging Consciousness or Kasibulan). The founding of Kasibulan and Kalayaan coincided with the founding of other groups that address a wide range of concerns—ranging from culture to political participation and health, establishment of a government women’s desk at the CCP, and the effecting of structural change through revolution. They include the revolutionary group Malayang Kilusan ng Bagong Kababaihan (Free Movement of New Women or Makibaka), established shortly before Marcos declared martial law; the militant coalition Gabriela; the Council for Primary Health; the Philippine Art Educators Association; and the Concerned Artists of the Philippines Women’s Desk. Also among the important women’s groups to come out was Women in Media Now or WOMEN, formed in 1982.

The assassination of Marcos’s principal opponent Ninoy Aquino on 21 Aug 1983 brought the country to another crossroads, with the political situation becoming extremely volatile. There was heightened militancy not only from the studentry and mass organizations but also from the upper and middle classes. New protest venues, like the elite enclave of Makati, were activated and became littered with yellow banners and confetti. At the same time, arrests and detentions, tortures and disappearances increased significantly. These conditions were reflected in paintings of suffering, such as in Baens Santos’s Malumbay si Ina (Mother Weeps) and Doloricon’s Hinagpis (Lamentation), both painted in 1983. The former shows a huge upside-down face of a mother weeping from the heavens; the latter is a montage panel juxtaposing images of hunger and poverty with that of a worker slain during a strike. In 1984, political detainees Fr Edicio dela Torre, Alan Jazmines, Noel Etabag, and Manuel Mario Guzman held a group show at Sining Kamalig showing nightmarish images of solitary confinement, torture, and their intense psychological effects along with the themes of death and resurrection and the hope for freedom.

A wide range of symbols and rallying figures emerged during this period of the regime’s decline. One of the most notable is the Justice for Aquino, Justice for All mural, which bore the faces of martyrs Macli-ing Dulag, Dr Bobby de la Paz, Edgar Jopson, Dr Johnny Escandor, and Ninoy Aquino. Young artist Manuel Gutierrez, who was himself slain later in a military encounter, produced a mural Fight for the People’s Right to Know, Fight for Press Freedom, 1986. Also in homage to the martyrs, Baens Santos painted Alay sa Bagong Bayani (Offering to the New Hero) in 1984 (Guillermo 2001).

 

Themes related to hope, regeneration, and renewal were also evident in some artists’ works, such as Baens Santos’s Bagong Pinay (New Filipina), Fernandez’s Arko ng Pagkakaisa (Arch of Unity), which showed various classes and sectors joining together to mourn a slain hero draped with a Philippine flag, symbolizing all those who were martyred in the struggle. Fernandez’s Hanap Ay Laya (Freedom Is What We Want), 1984, expressed the people’s aspiration for freedom and sovereignty through a mother-and-child figure draped in the colors of the Philippine flag.

Clenched fists symbolizing militancy and defiance were transformed into hands creating an eloquent language of production and struggle in Manrique’s Hand series. Fernandez’s painting of rows of feet of people from all classes marching beside a yellow-draped figure symbolized the unity of the rich and the poor around a common cause. Ninoy’s assassination became the subject of numerous paintings and even became a theme of one Metrobank art competition. Birds—live and as subject matter—along with confetti strips cut from telephone yellow pages, also became popular as symbols of freedom, unity, and aspirations. Colors also acquired different meanings: red symbolized the national democratic organizations; yellow was for moderate urban, middle-class groups supportive of Corazon “Cory” Aquino’s candidacy in the 1986 presidential snap elections and subsequent EDSA Revolt. The bifurcation between red and yellow forces is mirrored in spatial terms: Ugarte Field for the Makati elite and Plaza Miranda for the masses. The symbolic and spatial divisions reveal that while, on the surface, all classes and political persuasions were united in a common anti-Marcos cause, on a deeper level the wedge between the classes are so deep-seated. The radical potential of so-called people’s power was neutralized by middle-class and elite alternatives, who galvanized themselves as a less radical alternative to the militant mass and national democratic movement. Progressive personalities were gradually replaced by what Guillermo describes as “right-wing elements,” such as those identified with ultraconservative religious groups and individuals formerly in the military. An image that stood out in this period was that of a poster based on the photograph of a vigilante, Norberto Manero Jr, proudly displaying his grisly trophy of a human head, that of a progressive Italian priest Tulio Favali. In 1985, Manero’s group murdered Favali in a gruesome manner, which underlined the inhumane conditions of the time.

Marcos was deposed in 1986 and was succeeded by a member of two of the most enduring political dynasties in the Philippines—the Cojuangcos and Aquinos, a formation Marcos had sought to break. Marcos, however, became a new oligarch, along with his favored technocrats and cronies. The beginning of the end came after the assassination of opposition leader Benigno Aquino Jr. Aquino’s wife, Corazon Cojuangco Aquino, became the first president to assume office after 20 years of what is often referred to as the Marcoses’ conjugal dictatorship (Guillermo 2001, 12-13).

 

Political art initially became a platform of celebration of the overthrow of the Marcos dictatorship. The CCP, a contested site since its inception, opened up to a democratic space that enabled exhibits like Piglas, which featured the protest art of those previously excluded in its programming. Amidst the rejoicing, the social realists continued to be a cynical and critical voice in what they perceived to be a continuation of elite and bourgeoisie political leadership. In Baens Santos’s painting Congratulations to the Liberal Democrats, 1985, Cory is shown jumping with glee while the new elites applaud below. When it was becoming clear that the Cory administration was as vulnerable to corruption and as beholden to the United States as its predecessor, the euphoria waned; celebratory images dwindled and were replaced by images of disillusionment and even grimmer realities. The democratic space shrank in no time and was replaced by resumption of an even more vigorous military campaign in the countryside with the Aquino administration’s policy of “total war” against politicized peasant masses, coupled with her advocacy of vigilante groups from fanatic and criminal elements terrorizing rural communities.   Written by Flaudette May Datuin
