article.value: Historical Background

The post-Marcos political euphoria of the mid-1980s revolved around two poles. First, there was a populist turn manifested in an aversion to state intervention in culture as this was feared to be too associated with the excesses of the deposed regime. Second, there was a growing faith in the capacity of participatory and grassroots-led governance as foil to the centralized mode of cultural management that prevailed through the Marcos years. The consequent aspiration toward a dispersion of power away from the national cultural centers in Manila was proposed as a way to shift the focus from perceptibly elite, National Capital Region-centric art toward emergent local modes of art engagement cognizant of social and area-based nuances.

In the previous regime, art had served the purpose of the state and crowded out oppositional voices. Rather than enabling the imaginative capacity of Filipinos to creatively engage with complex questions about identity, development, and change, Marcos’s cultural managers were perceived by the larger public as merely perpetuating the status of the already privileged. Marcos also had a virtual stranglehold over official narrative-generating institutions such as the National Museum of the Philippines, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, the Museum of Philippine Art, Design Center of the Philippines, the Manila Film Center, state-controlled tri-media, and even the physical architecture that would hold up a fabricated image of the New Society.

With the new administration of Corazon Aquino, a dissident culture that had previously been relegated to the underground during martial law was hopefully construed as the alternative direction for Philippine art, given the newly liberalized state of affairs. The unarticulated myth that underlay post-EDSA public perception was that the Aquino government could work on a fresh, clean slate. The consequent power vacuum brought on by appointees of the past regime yielding their posts occasioned a radical changing of the guard. This new set of cultural administrators and gatekeepers set out to craft a new macrovision of how culture and power should interface. Whereas before they were shutout artists, cultural workers, and intellectuals, they became cultural administrators who advocated a pluralist and multivocal notion of art production and circulation.

It was in the succeeding administration of President Fidel V. Ramos that an umbrella organization was created to oversee culture and the arts. Previously, in 1992, Aquino’s first exective order creating the Presidential Commission on Culture and the Arts (PCCA) was finally enacted into law, which formally created the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA). In 1998, Ramos initiated the creation of a National Museum Complex where the Finance and the Department of Tourism Buildings were to be used by the National Museum. First Lady Amelita “Ming” Ramos was also active in the art scene, working with Manila Mayor Alfredo Lim in the reconstruction of the Metropolitan Museum. Ming Ramos also started the Katutubong Filipino Foundation to revive Filipino traditions through livelihood, arts, crafts, and culture.

Amidst these developments, the art world was not spared from controversies in the succeeding decades after the EDSA Revolt, when democratic processes in art making and practices came in conflict with institutional power. In 2009, President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo named five artists as recipients of the National Artist awards. These artists were not in the list of the original candidates submitted by the selection committee composed of members from the NCCA and the CCP, which outraged civilians and artists. In the same year, a petition was filed in the Supreme Court by National Artists Bienvenido Lumbera and Virgilio Almario to prevent Malacañan from conferring the award to these artists. The Supreme Court voided the Arroyo proclamation in 2013.

The term of President Benigno Aquino III witnessed an important controversy. In 2011, Poleteismo, a work by Mideo Cruz that was part of the Kulo (Boil) exhibit at the CCP, enraged the conservative and religious sectors of society due to the juxtaposition of religious images with pop icons, condoms, and wooden penises. It generated so much controversy that the CCP had to close down the exhibit due to “vandalism and threats to its persons” (GMA News Online 2011). A case was filed against Cruz and CCP officials by lawyer Manuel Dayrit of the Kapatiran party list accusing them of violating Article 201 of the Revised Penal Code on obscene exhibitions and indecent shows. In 2013, the Office of the Ombudsman ruled that Poleteismo did not fall under “obscene” exhibitions. It further added that the work was not “lacking in serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value as to remove it from the ambit of constitutionally protected expression” (Office of the Ombudsman 2013).

Other highlights in art during the Aquino administration was the turnover of the Department of Tourism Building to the National Museum; the display of Philippine artifacts in the possession of museums abroad for the exhibit Philippines: Archipel des Échanges (Philippines: An Archipelago of Exchange), 2013, at the Musée du Quai Branly in Paris, France; and the Philippines’ participation in the 56th Venice Biennale in 2015 after a 50-year hiatus. The Philippine Art Venice Biennale was a collaborative project of the NCCA, the Department of Foreign Affairs, and the Office of Senator Loren Legarda. In the midst of the resurgence of the presence of Philippine art in various global platforms, the articulation of the shifting meaning of the Filipino experience in the local, national, and diasporic contexts has defined the production, circulation, and reception of art.
Decentralizing Art Institutions
The move toward the reorientation of how art is understood post-1986 invariably involves restructuring art institutions guided by the lessons of “People Power” and popular democracy.

The Cultural Center of the Philippines. One of the most important tasks at hand after EDSA 1 was the dismantling of the earlier image of state-run institutions, like the Cultural Center of the Philippines, as elitist. Right after assuming the presidency, Corazon Aquino appointed Ma. Teresita Roxas as president of the CCP and Nicanor Tiongson as artistic director. Together with several artists and cultural workers, Tiongson then set out to draft the five thrusts that would guide the reorientation of the CCP. The five thrusts were Filipinization, democratization, decentralization, promotion of artistic excellence, and reorientation of international exchanges (Tiongson 2009). The new administrators sought to open the doors of the CCP to artists and audiences of all classes, inviting them in from peripheral regions. Filipinization was at the core of these changes and the new CCP worked to actively support Filipino artists and their works and to promote them not only locally but in other countries as well.

When the new team took over the CCP on 15 Jul 1986, a series of consultations were held to hear the voices of past administrative officers and artistic directors of the CCP and artists. These consultations led to the implementation of changes such as the restructuring of the CCP into a National Coordinating Center for the Arts. This move led to the opening of the CCP to artists who were marginalized during the Marcos regime, such as the social realists, singers like the Patatag, and theater groups like the Philippine Educational Theater Association (Tiongson 2009). The CCP Board was also reconstituted to accommodate not only government appointees and those from the business sector but also artists such as CB Garrucho, Cora Iñigo, Erlinda Fule, Rodrigo Perez III, Leandro Locsin, Jaime Zobel, Oscar Ledesma, and Manolo Agustines. The CCP also invited the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group and the University of Santo Tomas Symphony Orchestra to join the expanding resident companies. In the spirit of democratization, the CCP became open to all art styles and legitimized popular art and showcased them through exhibitions such as Tony Velasquez’s komiks Kenkoy; programs such as the open-air Seranata ng mga Banda, featuring local bass bands; and symposia, screenings, and publications of popular films. In its attempt to evolve from its static elitist position to an active democratic institution, the CCP reached out not only to artists but to Filipino audiences across sectors. This was done by bringing resident companies to perform in venues outside Metro Manila and busing high school students in to watch plays and movies in the CCP.

One of the most significant contributions of the CCP during this era was the reorganization of its outreach and exchange department. In its thrust toward decentralization, art councils were formed in cities outside Metro Manila that would be responsible for “gathering local visual, performing and literary artists into an organization that would take care of developing and supporting their own original productions according to the priorities and plans that they would identify and pursue for themselves.” These art councils received in-service training in arts management from the CCP in order to create viable and sustainable programs. These councils also received grants from the CCP to train their artists and to encourage them to produce original works of art showcasing their local culture. Art festivals were held in the regions rather than in Manila. Aside from giving grants, the CCP also helped local artists raise funds for their projects by bringing performers, artwork and film exhibitions to their locales.

The thrust on Filipinization was concretized by programs ensuring that Filipino artists would benefit from foreign artists invited to the center. Workshops, performances, master classes, artist exchanges, and residencies were organized through funding actively sourced from embassies and patrons. In 1988, the Museo ng Kalinangang Filipino (Museum of Philippine Culture) was opened to showcase a thematic exhibit based on the Filipino concept of diwa (consciousness) utilizing Philippine ethnographic materials to highlight the integration of art, aesthetics, and everyday life. In 1994, the publication of the 10 volumes of the Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, together with the monographs and video productions of Tuklas Sining (Discovering Art), helped in promoting Philippine art and culture to a wider public.

The CCP also renamed its performing venues, rehearsal halls, and galleries after Filipino artists. The Main Theater was renamed after Nicanor Abelardo, the Little Theater after Aurelio V. Tolentino, the Studio Theater after Huseng Batute, and the Dream Theater after Manuel Conde. The Main Gallery was renamed Bulwagang Juan Luna, the Small Gallery was called Bulwagang Fernando Amorsolo while the Little Theater lobby was called Bulwagang Carlos V. Francisco. CCP instituted venue grants to visual artists to showcase their work wherein various spaces of the building also became exhibit spaces. The corridors at the second, third, and fourth floors became Pasilyo Vicente Manansala, Pasilyo Guillermo Tolentino, and Pasilyo Victorio Edades, respectively. The balcony and exterior grounds also became exhibit venues, especially for installation art.

In the succeeding decades, the primary thrusts of Filipinization, democratization, decentralization, and artistic excellence remained at the core of the CCP’s goals. The CCP continued its outreach programs, supporting Filipino artists and arts in different regions.

By the late 1990s, the cultural development fund would dwindle and reach a critical level, necessitating the succeeding administrations to augment it by lobbying for increases in the annual budget from the government, raising funds through corporate sponsorship and cost-cutting measures (CCP 1999, 4-6). Other problems faced by the succeeding administrators included the deterioration of the physical structure of the CCP Complex. In 1999, a plan was drafted for the development of half of the 60-hectare CCP Complex for commercial purposes to help fund the institution’s artistic ventures and projects. By 2004, the CCP had implemented various public relations projects, among them the publication of the CCP News Bulletin, the adoption of a new corporate logo, the publication of “high-impact” feature articles in print media, and the establishment of tri-media networking in the regions (CCP 2004). In 2005, the CCP expanded its focus in response to globalization and the opening of world markets. To address the danger of cultural invasion by more powerful and dominant cultures, the CCP formulated a national plan to develop and promote micro, small, and medium artistic and cultural enterprises. Projects were geared toward supporting artists and groups, encouraging them to develop viable and sustainable operations (CCP 2005). The CCP also geared its performances, festivals, cultural events, exhibitions, film showings, and dialogues to reach Filipinos in other countries.

The National Commission on Culture and the Arts. Before the initial euphoria of EDSA waned, members of the Concerned Artists of the Philippines convened to draft a comprehensive blueprint for the creation of a Ministry of Culture. Aquino’s response to this call was the creation of the PCCA through Executive Order 118. It was not until 1992 that this executive order was enacted into law creating the National Commission for Culture and the Arts through Republic Act 7356. The NCCA acts as an umbrella organization enacting policies, coordinating and disbursing grants “for the promotion of Philippine Arts and Culture,” and administering the National Endowment Fund for Culture. Executive Order 80 placed the CCP, the National Historical Institute, the National Museum, the National Library, and the Records, Management and Archives Office under the NCCA. Republic Act 9155 subsumed the Komisyon sa Wikang Filipino under the NCCA.

The new law underpinning the NCCA as an umbrella cultural institution was to usher in a broader platform of cultural governance that could, in principle, restrain any singularly powerful culture czar or patron from unilaterally deciding the fate of arts and culture produced under state largesse. The reconstituted NCCA institutionalized its core of artist-volunteers as national committee members, such as Jose Joya and Mauro Malang, to give these individuals a way to evolve policy and programs from the ground up. Sitting on these committees were pools of artists and cultural workers who were expected to serve as expert voices to feed into how administrators and bureaucrats would logistically oversee a pioneering cultural endowment fund. This endowment fund was gained primarily from a fraction of travel taxes and proceeds from the Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corporation.

Access to such highly contested resources would, over the years, become a source of tension among artists with contending affinities. The expectation was that both non-aligned individuals and organizations would have a level playing field within which to compete for monies that could help realize projects that might not find patronage elsewhere. However, it would not take too long after the fervor of the 1986 EDSA Revolt for this to wane. Alongside the limited means to accommodate all competing interests, the initial optimism became weighed down by several factors. The uneven capacities of artists and artists’ organizations to navigate the intricacies of grant administration, the incompatibility between the working processes of government and creative agents, and the narrow dissemination of information about opportunities for artists were some of the hindrances faced by artists. These eventually led to the slowing down of communication and decision-making. Some disenfranchised sectors were ambivalent toward state mechanisms, which they perceived as disadvantaging practices that did not easily fall within prescribed tropes such as identity, authenticity, and representative culture. Some also perceived that government programming had become precariously more market-oriented.

Museums. The post-EDSA 1 period saw the closure of the Museum of Philippine Art and the Design Center of the Philippines. Despite the meager budget allocated for the National Museum in 1986, the museum managed to make modest improvements in their collection, research projects, and branch museums development (National Museum 1986). The Archaeology Division of the National Museum was created in 1988 to conduct researches on prehistory and protohistory of the Philippines through archaeological excavations of land and water sites (National Museum 1986). In the mid-1990s, President Fidel V. Ramos initiated the creation of a National Museum Complex where the Finance and the Department of Tourism (DOT) Buildings were to be turned over for use by the National Museum. The Finance Building was turned over in 1995 and with the transfer of the Senate to Quezon City, the Executive House was also incorporated into the National Museum Complex. Upon the approval of Republic Act 8492 (National Museum Act of 1998) on 12 Feb 1998, the National Museum was reestablished as “an autonomous government trust instrumentality under a Board of Trustees … which designated the President of the Philippines as the Honorary Chairman and Patron of the National Museum” (Official Gazette 2016). Also in 1998, the Museum of the Filipino People in the converted Finance Building was inaugurated, featuring ethnographic materials and interactive modules. In 2013, plans were under way to turn the DOT Building into the Museum of Natural History. As a repository of the Philippines’ natural and cultural heritage, the National Museum has continued to strengthen its collections in the succeeding decades after EDSA 1. The National Museum also continues to undertake researches, exhibitions, projects, and programs in the fields of natural science, social science, culture, and the arts.

The Metropolitan Museum (MET) continued its operation right after the EDSA Revolt but adopted a new policy of “art for all” with the aim of bringing the museum closer to Filipinos. Aside from having regular exhibitions of Philippine arts, the MET refined their objectives to include the appreciation of arts of the everyday, expansion of viewership, acquisition of art references from other countries for the appreciation of the Filipino audience, and upgrading of its services and administration (Paulino 2005, 36-7). The museum also featured a bilingual, didactic approach in its first post-EDSA exhibition. Instructional materials, such as signages, guide notes, teachers’ museum assistants, and monographs, were written in both English and Filipino (Paulino 2005, 37). To further Filipinize the museum’s image, Felice Sta. Maria, then director of the MET, conceptualized the brown banig (reed woven mats) as opposed to the sterile, elitist, and Western concept of the museum as a white cube. Using the Filipinos’ affinity with colors, the museum walls were sometimes painted and “academic labels were formulated into poetic thought pockets which were trite but high impact” (Paulino 2005, 37). The fluid spaces were filled with more materials and the once silent halls were now jarred by piped-in music. What made MET different from the other museums at this time was its focus on the institution as a nonformal space for continuing learning and value formation (Paulino 2005, 37). The MET offered museum apprenticeship for students, volunteer programs for professionals, and traveling exhibits. In the 1990s, it was mired by controversy when rumors spread that the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) was to evict the MET and sell its collections. Many artists and cultural workers rallied behind the MET, arguing that it was an important institution that provided spaces for artists to exhibit their works. The controversy died down when the BSP dispelled rumors of the museum’s eviction. President Fidel V. Ramos also intervened and ordered Secretary Teofisto Guingona Jr, First Lady Amelita Ramos, and Manila Mayor Alfredo Lim to assist the MET. A newly renovated MET was then inaugurated in 1994. In the 2000s, MET director Victorino Manalo conceptualized a fluid connection between museums and communities through its four-year program Sining at Pamayanan (Paulino 2005, 42-3). This concept was applied in Quiapo: The Arts of a City District, which showcased not only the arts of Quiapo but problems such as overpopulation. With this focus, the MET tapped art as a resource and source of insight to societal issues and problems, “thus revitalizing the museum as useful to a broader audience” (Manalo in Paulino 2005, 43).

New museum spaces also opened in the 1990s. While the Government Service Insurance System (GSIS) started acquiring artworks in the 1980s, it was only in the 1990s when space was alloted for an art gallery. In Apr 1996, the Museo ng Sining of the GSIS was inaugurated, housing the works acquired by the GSIS, with Dr David Baradas as its first museum director. In 1987, the Jorge B. Vargas Museum opened in the University of the Philippines. The museum houses the personal collection of Vargas consisiting of more than 500 works from the 19th century to the 1960s.

Commercial Galleries and Artist-Run Spaces. Fewer than 10 galleries were active in the early years of the Aquino administration, among which were La Galerie of Alliance Française, Madrigal Center, West Gallery, and Brix Gallery (Yusi 2016). The scant number of galleries was attributed to the economic problems that beset the early years of the Aquino administration. The gallery scene began to pick up again in the 1990s when the economy started recovering from its initial slump. The early 1990s saw the opening of Art Walks and galleries in malls, which came about after the successful art show of Juvenal Sanso in SM Megamall (Yusi 2016). With the successful sale of Sanso’s artworks not only to collectors but also to casual passersby, SM’s administration thought it was possible to bring art closer to the public (Yusi 2016). They then transformed level 4 of the SM Megamall as an Art Walk, housing galleries and exhibition spaces. This success was followed later by new galleries in Shangri-La Plaza, Alabang Town Center, and Glorietta 4. In the 1990s, Cubao Expo in Quezon City, which used to be the Marikina Shoe Expo, attracted artists and business people to open galleries and art shops due to the low rent. Due to rental increases in the following decades, only a few galleries have survived in this area today (Yusi 2016). In 2006, Pasong Tamo (now Don Chino Roces Ave) in Makati was transformed from a business district, mostly consisting of car garage shops, to a creative district of galleries, furniture shops, and advertising agencies (del Rosario 2016).

While galleries continued to open across the country, earlier established artist-run ventures, like Pinaglabanan Galleries and ArtLab, would close shop or shift operational modes from gallery operations to project management by the 1990s. Rather than tending established modern artists, commercial galleries opted to support contemporary work, which would later become the staples of the current mainstream gallery circuit. These include Contreras Sculpture, Crucible Gallery, Finale Art File, Galeria de las Islas, Galeria Duemila, Gallery Genesis, Liongoren Art Gallery, Madrigal Art Center, among others. These made up the first set of galleries that would turn out such collaborative projects as the themed joint exhibit series Art Manila, and preliminary research for artist raisonnés of National Artists under the NCCA’s gallery committee grant window.

In the 1990s, alternative art spaces were opened by artists who did not want to work within the established gallery system and who felt that there was never enough cultural and infrastructural support from the government (del Rosario 2016). Examples of nonprofit artist-run spaces are Surrounded by Water, Big Sky Mind and Green Papaya Art Projects, Artery, Black Soup, the Department of Avant-Garde Cliches, Future Prospects, Junk Shop, Lost Projects, Kanto, Mag:net, 98B, Post, Sands Gallery, Sigwa da, Syano, Tambayang Makiling, Third Space, and Underground.

Over the years, with the aging of artists and patrons and diminished circulation of work in the secondary market, commercial spaces and sites that came after them, like 1335 Mabini, Brix Gallery, Manila Contemporary, Silverlens, among others, became more relatively in sync with the programming of artist-run spaces, which were more open-ended. This shift in the mainstream, along with the accelerated organizing among artists, had, at various junctures, parallels outside Manila, such as Café Memento and Mariyah Gallery in Dumaguete, Enigmata Treehouse in Camiguin, Greenhouse Effect Gallery Ili-Likha Artist Village, Tam-awan Village and VOCAS in Baguio, Kamarikutan in Palawan, Karumata in Cagayan de Oro, Linya Gallery in Iligan, Luná in Cebu, Orange Gallery in Bacolod, Project Space Pilipinas in Quezon Province, and others.

Assertions of Autonomy and Art Initiatives. The emergence of the less structured, informally operating artist-run organizations was an international phenomenon viewed as organic response to citizens’ fatigue over seeing culture instrumentalized, with art being made to service traditional agendas of individual politicians or by the state as a whole. As artist-run ventures globally are wont to do, these usually spartan undertakings variably succeeded in sustaining themselves. Meanwhile, older formations—such as the Art Association of the Philippines, Black Artists in Asia, Concerned Artists of the Philippines, Kababaihan sa Sining at Bagong Sibol na Kamalayan, Pampanga Arts Guild, the Saturday Group of Artists—and other media-based, advocacy-driven, art school-born groupings, like Angono Ateliers Association and Junior Ateliers, Anino Shadowplay, Anting-Anting Artists’ Circle, Grupong ANG, Hulo, New World Disorder, Printmakers Association of the Philippines, Salingpusa (then Sanggawa), Society of Philippine Sculptors, TAMA, Tutok, UGATLahi, among many others, would persevere or hibernate within an increasingly crowded field.

Outside of Manila, the Baguio Arts Guild admirably ran its pioneering international art festivals (Baguio International Arts Festival or BIAF) through 2002, with the Tam-awan International Art Festivals and AXIS Baguio taking up after the BIAF’s demise. The Neo-Angono Artists Collective, on the other hand, would begin its annual public art festivals in 2004. Artist-staged exchanges between organizations would also yield an organic translation of forms, such as installation and performance, in cross-regional contexts. The network of Visayan artists’ organizations grew in size as it gathered for region-wide assemblies like VIVA ExCon beginning 1990, while the much more modest network of Davao–Cagayan de Oro–Iligan artists and organizations that fueled the Mindanaoan initiative Panit Bukog (Skin and Bone) was also enabled by curator Bobi Valenzuela in 2004. These artists’ formations would reach out to local and international peers as it had become more feasible to travel for purposes of residencies, exchanges, and reciprocal exhibitions.

To a certain degree, the tussle between programmatic and more open-ended organizing and laboratory-type work serves as an alternative force to official and market-driven culture. The counterbalancing of these politicized cultural practices has become a subject in some artists’ works. An example is Filipino-American filmmaker Angel Shaw’s 2014 project, Markets of Resistance: A Visual and Interdisciplinary Trade-Barter Exhibition, which consisted of intrepid installations and performances and the occupation of market stalls in Baguio City’s public market. In this event, artists were asked to make objects that could be bartered in kind where no money was exchanged. The exhibition decentralized market forces by resituating Baguio as a precolonial site where barter trade was practiced and by bringing the works of artists to the general public. The event or show was meant as a process of “connecting people and ideas rather than of producing” (de Veyra 2015).

This pull toward decentralization may be seen as a global phenomenon, with the concentration of political power shifting from nation-states to global capital. The seeming dissolution of a singular notion of creative site of practice is being fueled by the increasing mobility of Filipinos moving in incremental waves to territories in need of labor to fill in cultural capital gaps in what would later be construed as creative industries. For example, visual artists seek employment as animators for global entertainment companies abroad. However, the thriving of popular movements and developmental NGOs able to reach communities without rigid protocols and beyond traditional political centers provided momentum to artist-initiated and community-run spaces and cultural initiatives. Artists disinclined to work within imposed megastructures found it possible to resist global consumerist trends.

Artist-initiated museums, such as those of Ben Cabrera and Ramon Orlina, are another dimension of self-production and circulation. This is an emergent trend in Asia along with self-published works, like those on J. Elizalde Navarro, Napoleon Abueva, Gus Albor, Phyllis Zaballero, among others; collector-initiated publications like Art after War; and the series of themed releases from the collection of Paulino and Hetty Que, which includes Meaning to Be Modern, Philippine Paintings from 1907 to 1959, and Imagining Identity: 100 Filipino Self-Portraits.

Alternatives to a Monolithic Culture amidst the Need for Distinction. Over the past three post-EDSA decades, the state continues to count on its cultural agencies to attend to its need to build consensus around notions of patriotism, citizenship, and governance. Thus state mechanisms, such as awards and grants, continue to recognize artists and cultural workers. Aside from the art grant mechanisms set up under the post-Marcos National Commission for Culture and the Arts, state recognition for the arts would eventually get reestablished by way of the continued awarding of the National Artists, the reestablishment of the Gawad CCP para sa Sining in 1989, and the institution of the Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan in 1992 to redress the perceived bias against the work done by traditional and folk artists. By 1999, the Cultural Center of the Philippines not only launched its Centennial Honors for the Arts but also revived the Thirteen Artists Awards.

The National Artists for visual arts recognized during this period include Federico Alcuaz, Benedicto Cabrera, Francisco Coching, Abdulmari Imao, Jose Joya, Ang Kiukok, Cesar Legaspi, Arturo Luz, J. Elizalde Navarro, and Hernando Ocampo; the Manlilikha ng Bayan awardees, on the other hand, are Ginaw Bilog, Salinta Monon, Lang Dulay, Darhata Sawabi, Haja Amina Appi, Eduardo Mutuc, Magdalena Gamayo, and Teofilo Garcia. Visual artists accorded the Gawad CCP, the institution’s lifetime achievement award, include Brenda Fajardo, Roberto Chabet Rodriguez, Pitoy Moreno, and Ben Farrales. Meanwhile, the first batch of CCP Thirteen Artist Awardees after 1986 is composed of Agnes Arellano, Roberto Feleo, Peter de Guzman, Pardo de Leon, Dan Raralio, Popo San Pascual, Jose Tence Ruiz, and Gerardo Tan, awarded in 1988.

Moreover, private platforms such as the Ateneo Art Awards and national art competitions put up by corporations—like the Metrobank Foundation’s M.A.D.E., Philippine Art Awards of the Philip Morris Group of Companies, and the long-running student competition launched by Pilipinas Shell Corporation—have broadened the modes of validation in the visual arts.

As Filipinos continue to move, settle, and think about their own sense of place and evolve more complex ideas about home, authenticity, and creative translation amidst rapidly changing contexts of everyday culture, artists and cultural workers are now more frequently dealing with the exchange of concepts, forms, and the technology in the production of art. Thus the privileging of identity discourse as a theme, which firmly took hold after World War II, has mellowed and given way to more vibrant formulations of what constitutes Filipino creativity, relevant content, and viable creative space. What has become increasingly evident in the work of younger artists is the veering toward a more globalized thematic. This stands in contrast to the much more introspective stream of the 1980s and partially of the 1990s. Partly due to the ease in which information now travels digitally, artists and organizers have taken on post-identity questions that range from notions of global citizenship, queries on migration, climate change, and consumerism, which are shared across many national sites. Artists also tap digital platforms to present their work and explore alternate modes of producing art, which also make possible interfaces with those beyond Philippine borders.

Among other triggers, the diversified media sphere has led to the consolidation of bigger museum institutions as they have sought to align programming and audience development, the sharing and exchange of resources, and synching of expertise. On the other hand, patron relations have also utilized these alignments to give rise to multi-venue exhibitions featuring single-artist projects as in the case of the 2008 His Art, Our Heart Fernando Amorsolo seven-museum program, and the Half a Century of BenCab series of events in 2015. As for the NCCA, increasing privileging of ethnolinguistic programming under the present leadership has been behind the annual Dayaw festivals, and where even the NCCA’s annual Philippine art festivals have emphasized the trope of indigeneity. Some of these initiatives have been notably spectacle-scale international exposure events, such as the sending of key cultural objects for the Quai Branly exhibition Philippines: An Archipelago of Exchange, 2013. This happened alongside kindred private initiatives, such as the San Francisco Asian Art Museum exhibition Philippine Gold: Treasures of Forgotten Kingdoms, 2015-16.

Decentralized Discourses of Art. The mid-1980s saw the realigning of political borders in Europe’s post-Cold War environs and the contingent wearing away of long-running dictatorships in postcolonial governments in Asia and Latin America. Alongside this phenomenon was the reshaping of histories and their production. Virtually throughout the Asian region, the shared project of many local scholars became the writing of more contextualized accounts of their own modernities and contemporaneities, and the writing back of evidences of precolonial culture into their own histories amidst imperial impositions from within Asia itself and/or Euro-America. This instinctive recourse to a self-determined present and prouder past would slowly gain ground and become institutionalized through area studies as well as interdisciplinary courses in various universities and research centers.

The fluidity of art categories affected curatorial practices as seen in the way exhibitions are no longer categorically distinguished as exclusively showing art or the solely ethnographic. The transdisciplinal questions posed by Marian Pastor-Roces in Pang-ulo: Filipino Ideas about Heads, Headgear and Head of Community at the National Museum, 2005, and those asked in the series curated by Patrick Flores—Influx: Transpositions in Philippine Modernism, Intimation: Compromises of Self, Incarnation: Disarming Figurations, Inclination: Across Origin, Within Sight, and Inculcation: Museum as Nation—also at the National Museum, 2006, reveal this wearing down of borders. Still another illustrative case is the series of NCCA-funded national visual arts exhibitions called Sungdu-an (Confluence), which was first undertaken by curators Virgilio Aviado, Bobi Valenzuela, and Imelda Cajipe-Endaya in 1996 and which went on till 2009 with curators Dennis Ascalon, Irma Lacorte, Claro Ramirez, and Christopher Rollo. Some of the significant lessons borne of the Sungdu-an experience included cultural workers developing a more acute sense of the disparate conditions faced by artists and organizers working out of Manila who often had to make do given the dearth in suitable venues, publications, channels for feedback, and updated training.

Meanwhile, the critical literature on visual art produced after martial law still pales in comparison to that seminal era when both state and private interests converged in churning out titles such as Archipelago, Filipino Heritage, the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Kayamanan series, Pamana, Philippine Art Supplement, and San Juan, among many others. Some significant publications that have come forth since 1986 are the CCP’s Ani, Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, Kultura, and Tuklas Sining; NCCA’s Araw and Sanghaya; the Reader’s Digest’s Kasaysayan volumes; and artist-initiated publications Pananaw: Philippine Journal of Visual Arts and Transit. The increasingly professionalized infrastructure of the gallery system made competitive with the influx of foreign dealers and gallerists pursuing Filipino artists has also spurred the more consistent publication of catalogues both for local and art fair-bound showings. On the more commercial front are magazines like Art Plus. Apart from limited-edition artists’ books and the occasional privately funded tomes, such as Artes delas Filipinas: Private Collections, 2009, and Without Walls: A Tour of Philippine Paintings at the Turn of the Millennium, 2010, a modest number of substantial material on precolonial culture went to press, such as Paths of Origin: The Austronesian Heritage, 2011, Ancestral Gold, 2012, and Philippines: Archipelago of Exchange, 2013. The onset of primarily web-hosted writing, on the other hand, is being undertaken by young enterprising initiatives—such as Planting Rice, 98B, DiscLab, Diskurso, among others—which are exploring how digital formats enable critique and general discourse rendered in multimedia. Apart from initiating project-based research, exhibitions, and/or administering modest residencies/fellowships, these platforms have turned out writing consisting of reportage and critique alongside increasingly interdisciplinary academe-initiated volumes such as Humanities Diliman, Kritika Kultura, Philippine Humanities Review, Philippine Studies, etc.

article.value: From the 1986 EDSA Revolt onward, artists have continued to defy categories and ready-made formulations about how art should figure in the public sphere. Simultaneously, adherents of more classical and traditional practice continue to produce work that may or may not easily get enfolded into the market and contemporary discourse. In general, however, artists who receive attention are those who more readily find recourse in pastiche or appropriation by weaving together discrepant motifs, toning down singular authorship, and occasionally refusing to deal with historicization by resorting to iconoclasm, parody, and irony. The broad range of work produced runs the gamut of the patronizingly representative, the frankly didactic, to the loosely woven together pop and folk culture references posed as diatribes against mainstream thought systems.

The digital platform has become a broadly accessible channel that allows younger, less-privileged artists, organizers, and writers to circumvent the much more heavily guarded institutional routes that are generally slower to take their practice into the larger realm of the newer media. The compacted formats and speeds at which information has become available through Web 2.0 and higher enable not just the production of alternate discourse but also the making and circulating of artistic work in modes previously known to and within reach of only a few. The emergence of memes, zines, sound work, video, photography, and bantering among artists and thinkers via the informal and sometimes clandestine chatter over portable media like pirate radio and social network platforms extends the possibilities of self-curation and building up of contact circles. Works in these forms also spread through wider circuits that are increasingly cheaper to work with and transmit through. This is done by activating physical and virtual spaces through paralegal or bootleg occupations of sites, the making of sound environments, performance, and video art that may or may not be crowdsourced. More importantly, these newer modes of making and encountering art occasion a comparatively more participatory counterflow of ideas. These channels facilitate interaction, even sometimes enabling more frequent physical and virtual homecomings or reintroductions of Filipino artists previously less visible to local art publics. One clear-cut case is David Medalla’s London Biennale extending satellite presences in other continents where Filipino and non-Filipino artists have chosen to respond to his mega art spectacle.

Nevertheless, the swift inroads in digital imaging technology and networked data interfaces have indeed spurred a much increased ability among artists in general so that they are able to self-document and, in a real sense, wield control over their own public representation. This development, and the emergence of more active and aggressive artist-curators, also patently broadens the democratic space for practice that does not always readily fit into categories set by academe and other cultural institutions with specific agendas. One-off, transient online platforms as modes of making sites of art practice have, for instance, made possible a more organic though not always unproblematic fusing of the work of artists from various fields such as design, music, dance, theater, film, visual art, etc. Illustrative of this stream is the annual experimental sound art initiative called WSK, organized by Merv Espina with Tengal Drilon, who is also behind more project-based/event initiatives like SABAW Media Kitchen and Terminal Garden. Parallel to this is the Art in the Park pop-up mode already appropriated by real estate promoters who have been insinuating art into community programming through periodic events, including affordable art fairs. Reminiscent of the exploration in terms of space that occurred in the 1970s, other loosely-configured, multimedia, multisite, and avowedly public interventions have also been done by AXIS Baguio, Back to Square 1’s Off Site / Out of Sight, Neo-Angono’s annual public art festivals, 98B through its team-up with the Escolta commercial association, Windang Aesthetics Labor Army (W.A.L.A.) via the multi-collective Botcha squat occupations, and the several installments of the Bagasbas and Malasimbo festivals. As a whole, being able to take on the tasks of scripting and organizing have allowed artists themselves to craft their own narratives. Some artists even propose clashing stories about their own trajectories in relation to larger questions on art and culture.

article.value: International Circulation of Art. Exhibition platforms, whether brick or mortar or virtual, saw a rise of the occasional cross-regional exhibition platforms in fairs or private gallery settings, outpacing the need for art writing and criticism. One major difference between the 1990s and more recent decades is the lack of museum-scale displays of international art in the Philippines. These displays were previously made possible by organizations such as the Japan Foundation and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), which aggressively organized exchanges in the 1990s.

Prior to the broader opening up of both public and private opportunities for residencies, artists and cultural workers found support through multilateral undertakings—like the ASEAN Travelling Exhibit of Painting, Photography, and Children’s Art—across member countries. On other interstate institutional fronts, exchanges and conferences would be enabled by the ASEAN Committee on Culture and Information, Asia Society, the Australian Artists’ Regional Exchange, Southeast Asian Studies Regional Exchange Program, and later by other international windows like the Alliance Française Philippines networking-residency programs, Asian Cultural Council, and the Asian Public Intellectuals Fellowship of the Nippon Foundation. These meant an increased exposure and visibility for Philippine art alongside the heightened representation of Filipinos in the seminal Fukuoka Asian Art Shows, which evolved into the Fukuoka Triennale, and the Queensland Art Gallery’s Asia-Pacific Triennials prior to the proliferation of biennales across the world. Through the decades, Filipino artists would be traveling out to key international events—such as the biennales in Havana, Melbourne, Paris, Sydney, Tokyo, Yokohama, and Documenta, among others—as official Philippine representatives or as artists working out from their present countries of residence. The escalating importance of Asia-based platforms, such as those in Dhaka, Gwangju, Jakarta, Shanghai, Singapore, and Taipei, would subsequently serve to counterpoint the high-profile regional art fairs and local/international art auctions that now powerfully play into the trading and making of reputations of artists from the region. After a hiatus of 50 years, the Philippines returned to participate in the oldest perennial, the 2015 Venice Biennale, with a team made up of Patrick Flores, Manny Montelibano, and Jose Tence Ruiz under a curatorial platform Tie a String around the World, which plays up a reverse imperial trajectory in the Asian incursion into Europe of the Mongol military leader Genghis Khan.

The counterpoint to this development, however, are smaller-scale efforts to stage showings of work from both Philippine-based artists and their peers practicing elsewhere. Two examples of this would be the Galleon Trade exhibitions curated by Jenifer Wofford and done at Green Papaya Art Projects and Mag:net Gallery, 2007, and Collage Drop Outs curated by Isabel Ching and Mariano Ching at Finale Art File in 2011. The generally unstructured international exchange-residencies that have been undertaken through collectives, like 98B, Project Space Pilipinas, and Neo-Angono, have been generally sustained thus far. Meanwhile in the performance art circuit, the launching of international festivals beginning in the 1990s onward triggered a resurgence of performative work initially within high-traffic public spaces like Luneta and Malate, then later on taking festival content through the university circuit, and on the road through Philippine provinces and cities like Lipa, Batangas, Lingayen, Pangasinan, and Santiago, Isabela. These gestures of occupation of new spaces of production, reception, and circulation, which not only characterize work in performance but also in transmedia, might prove to be what distinguish this period from preceding robust developmental phases of Philippine art.

Philippine art has been aggressively collected by international museums as evidenced by acquisitions or commissions undertaken for the Fukuoka Asian Art Museum, the Queensland Art Gallery / Gallery of Modern Art, the Singapore Art Museum, and, more recently, Centre Georges Pompidou, the Guggenheim UBS MAP Global Art Initiative, the National Gallery Singapore, New Museum, and Mori Art Museum.

The globalization of economies resulted in an active market of art produced in Asia, including the Philippines. Thus art auction houses, such as Sotheby’s and Christies, have become active promoters in the circulation of artworks, possibly influencing aesthetic issues in conjunction with marketability. This easier access to once locked-off channels may in some way be seen as affecting the level of activity among artist-run spaces whose initiators inevitably get enfolded into the mainstream. This is also a demonstration of how the market is able to accommodate even what are initially posed as alternative practices. This phenomena may also be observed on the commoditization of artworks employing social realism and conceptual art.

Apart from an escalating presence in international auctions and the biennale-perennial circuit, an increasing number of pre-mid-career artists have been figuring in international initiatives such as Maria Taniguchi’s clinching of the 2015 Hugo Boss Prize. More senior artists have also been receiving recognition abroad, such as in the case of Carlos Villa’s archival material becoming accessioned by the Smithsonian; David Medalla’s exhibiting his work at Tate Britain, 2012; and the MAM Research 002: Who Was Roberto Chabet? initiative at Mori Museum, 2015.

In this volatile climate, a new set of artists would assert that their own subjectivities are in perpetual construction, producing works resistant to easy categories such as social realist-conceptual, local-global, and so on. Artists would argue for dynamic redefinitions due to how mobile and racially diverse Filipinos have become. And because of how inescapably tied up in culture change this idea of self and subjectivities was turning into, both artists and theorists caution against rigid pronouncements anchored on notions of racial purity and clear-cut territorial affinities. One such key example of this stream would be the series of exhibitions undertaken in Europe, Asia, and North America by the loose group of artists making up the Bastards of Misrepresentation, which include Poklong Anading, Yason Banal, Argie Bandoy, Bea Camacho, Lena Cobangbang, Louie Cordero, Maria Cruz, Gaston Damag, Arvin Flores, Dina Gadia, Robert Langenegger, Romeo Lee, Pow Martinez, Manuel Ocampo, Jayson Oliveria, Carlo Ricafort, Gerardo Tan, MM Yu, and Zoleta. Parallel to this deliberately nebulous stream of organizing is the continued work of nationalist political art organizations such as Alay Sining, Gerilya, Karatula, Molotov, Sining Bugkos, and other similar affiliations.

Contested responses to questions about how artists ought to negotiate with transnational forces bearing upon art’s autonomy and social functions reveal the tension between the individual capacity to enable continuities with regard to tradition, along with the creative momentum needed to effect transformation. Specifically in regard to internal and external migration, not a few artists have privileged still unfolding narratives variably grounded in appropriated positionalities, as opposed to those merely inherited and foreclosed within the confines of nation-states and other arbitrary localities. One concrete example of this is the work of Filipino-American Stephanie Syjuco, Empire Garden, 2015, where her live botanical rendering of the history of empire comes together in the form of an ongoing makeshift laboratory project that hopes to grow tobacco, cotton, indigo, poppy, and corn under artificial conditions. As more works get produced by artists of Filipino ancestry who live as transients or as dual citizens and thus may possess more than singular loyalties to any one country, questions of stake and patrimonial anchors have become more and more complicated and laborious to reconcile.
The Visual Arts: Themes, Materials, and Techniques

In the face of aggressive globalization and its effect on the human condition, theorists, critics, and historians have been challenged to develop an ability to read from and beyond immediate contexts as well as reckon with parallelisms in nearby country-states or territories with similar historico-cultural trajectories and parallel predicaments of definition, such as in Southeast Asia, the Pacific, and Latin America. Constant recalculations about how art and culture positions itself in regard to the categories of local-global-glocal continue to occupy policymakers and those working at the grassroots with their more immediate concerns of efficacy, legibility, and sustainability. The artist as consummate image and meaning-maker is expectedly thrust in this complex conditions.

The visual art forms that were produced post-1986 may be understood in thematical threads that saw the close integration of form, content, and discourses, affected by the modes of production, circulation, and reception of art in the local, national, and global spheres. While an older generation of artists continue to express through their painting, sculpture, printmaking, and photography, younger artists experimented with art forms that transcended the old art categories, such as installation art, which assemble objects in a given space; site-specific art, which include the particular nuances of the space into the artwork; performance art or the focusing on action or performativity as central to the artwork; video art, which employs the projection of moving images; digital art, which utilizes computer-generated images; sound art, which uses sound as core art element; transmedia art or the mixing of multiple media; and hypermedia arts, which employs gaming technology and components of networked elements.

Image-Making and Identity Discourse. Identity discourse as subject matter in art remains operative under these complex conditions albeit in a much more nuanced vein. Two winning pieces from the Philippine Art Awards help illustrate at least two approaches artists have adopted within the realm of figurative painting. First off is Alfredo Esquillo’s Daang Ligid-Krus, 1996, which demonstrates classical painting technique on what was then a novel painting ground of rubber. The work is a deft rendering of extremely lifelike details in a scene of folk religious devotees making their way through a devotional route laid out in maze configuration, which could be read as souls navigating predetermined paths even when counting on the existence of options. Specific points in the maze are punctuated by iconic folk motifs like town musicians, indigenized and infantilized Christ image, amulets, and other devotional instruments amidst secular devices like live TV sets, drink, and porn. Esquillo’s is a type of image-making that draws heavily from local references even as its narrative is not straightforwardly as prescriptive or moralistic as visual materials in school used to be mandated. This anecdotal slice is arguably open that multiple readings could be made around and about it. The second piece for consideration is Nona Garcia’s See Saw, 2000, which is indicative of how most Filipino artists remain preoccupied with draughtmanship—in this case, down to the creases, even as this work is coupled with an interest in addressing the realization that the most “real” of images are subject to the complexities of truth telling. See Saw is both verbal and visual pun, where the seen and unseen are dually questioned given that the painting of a chainsaw, however delicately bundled up and thus hidden, is remarkably realistic whereas the unwrapped chainsaw subjected to the piercing radiographic lenses of an X-ray machine is rendered visible but also almost unreal because of its being visually mediated through another layer of vision.

While demonstrating the kind of hyperrealist strain of image-making that continues to be popular among many Filipinos, these artists’ image-making practices also still do demonstrate the polarities in thinking about what is and what could be, and how mimesis or verisimilitude can or cannot be the be-all and end-all of seeing and knowing. The shock aesthetic that overlays the work of artists such as Jose Legaspi with his representations of homoerotic trauma, for instance, strongly challenges the inherently traditional association that hyperrealist painting has earned. Another work that hews to a graphic-conceptualist vein is Antipas Delotavo’s centennial mural Dantaon, 1998, which not only readily registers as a Philippine history narrative but also poses a conceptual challenge to the traditional view of history as tightly bound up through events and one-dimensional personages constructed by the writing of historians and the interventions of media and popular reading. The deliberately unfinished progression of characters and motion sequence illustrates how the visual communicates through both the cognitive and affective senses. Lastly, another demonstration of how figuration can be construed more conceptually is Lani Maestro’s drawings of body parts for her installation Poem without a Country, 1988, done in reference to human rights abuses perpetuated even during post-EDSA regimes. Just as in another piece, A Wound in the Lung, 1994, a room-size installation of a mound of soil within which a human-scale cavity was left, Maestro’s desire to engage with arguably humanist themes is rendered in the work subtly to perhaps not just resonate with narrowed local context like Philippine militarization but also to effect conversations with other visual cultures that may have affinities in experience, but not with such locally recognizable references.

Nonetheless, a more straightforwardly identitarian mode is still operative for other artists. In the case of National Artist BenCab, for instance, in regard to his already politically charged installments of the Sabel series, the female figurative motif has become more and more associated with a universalized reference to either a maternal icon for nation, or as stand-in for the everyday woman in swirling turn-of-the-century dress overlaid with plastic wrap. A more complicated position taken in regard to issues of subject and representation may be found in the work of Gaston Damag whose backhanded imaging of his roots in Banaue takes form in violence-laden vignettes of the bulol physically subjected to pressure and wearing down in exhibitionary contexts. This is in contrast to a predilection for nostalgically referring to a “purer” past seen in the practice of the de Guia brothers—Kidlat Jr in his photographic images of a rapidly transforming mountain city, Kabunian’s lowbrow aesthetic realized in collaborative and publicly sited mosaics, and Kawayan’s more urbane found object critique of globalizing influences trudging upon everyday Filipino consciousness.

These contrasting perspectives about how visual strategies play into questions of representation and critical inquiry are borne of a growing suspicion over national identity discourse flattening differences among ethnicities. Critics have construed this tendency as a ploy to lure artists into docile participation in visual homogenizing projects, of turning out uncritical citizens merely submitting to the self-indulging tenets of a form of globalization that perpetuates a sense of self without regard for communal contexts. Consequently, resistant strains have taken a broad range of forms and have unevenly been underpinned by theory and critique—with some work often coming across as knee-jerk impulse pushing artists to play anywhere between the continuum of aimless truant to sharp critic.

In no small part due to the digital sphere’s growing emphasis on self-fashioning manifested in the padding of profiles, blogging, avatar-making, and so on, the parallel turn to the self in biography-laced work of artists is also an evident stream of image construction. This is seen in differing degrees in the wide range of performative work of David Medalla, to the dour alter egos Lyra Garcellano crafts in her print and online comic strips. This conjuring of multiple selves and/or invoking of personal biography also manifests in other more tactile forms as in the punk sculpture tableau self-tribute of Romeo Lee, the folksy reference to Angono’s festival procession in Wire Tuazon’s casting himself for Endramada, and the printmaking gone three-dimensional stretched latex work of Ambie Abaño.

article.value: Even as a still resurgent critical impulse propels a significant amount of post-EDSA work done by elder social realists and younger activist-artists traversing the range from easel to mural painting and effigies, more work in the installative vein has also surfaced in this respect. Instances include Reamillo and Juliet’s site-specific reference to Marcos excesses and cover-ups in Black Hole, 1993, at the former Manila Film Center, and Buen Calubayan’s literally rat-infested On Spectacle and (Other) Awkward Rules on Killing by Means of Natural Selection, 2009, for the CCP Thirteen Artists exhibition of that year.

The Appropriation of Local Image/Object as Means to Decolonization. The propensity to employ what was counted as lost then found motifs and images of premodern and even colonial circulation is still popular among some artists. We note this persistent strain for instance in the painting and sculptural work of the Baldemor siblings Lito and Manuel, Nemiranda, the Blanco family of painters, among many others. There is also, among much younger practitioners, a period photography-pegged aesthetic that informs the collages of artists such as Joven Mansit, or earlier in Karen Flores’s and Mark Justiniani’s paintings from the 1990s onward as they invoked Damian Domingo’s tipos del pais illustrations to enable critique from an overtly historical perspective. The once highly potent political charge emitted by such images, however, has become neutered in the way some painters may have inadvertently participated in the circulation of these images as exotic tourist fare or as sheer stylistic flourish easily depoliticized through branding and the workings of hipsterism.

While not necessarily directly participating in decolonizing discourse, surrealist and abstract-inclined painters and sculptors working from an impulse to look broadly, and not just to Euro-America, have continued to produce competent work. Among these are Ronald Achacoso, Gus Albor, Zeus Bascon, Allan and Ivi Avellana-Cosio, Benjie and Zean Cabangis, Maria Cruz, Troy Ignacio, Eugene Jarque, Lao Lianben, Jose Mendoza, the father and son Romulo and Jonathan Olazo, Bernardo Pacquing, Imelda Pilapil, Roberto Robles, Rodolfo Samonte, Soler Santos, Nestor Vinluan, Reginald Yuson, Phyllis Zaballero, and Alvin Zafra, among many others.

What were initially called siteworks, environments, then eventually installations in the 1970s, art literature were born from a wide range of persuasions, from those referencing modernist discourse as seen in Nilo Ilarde’s works literally chipping away at the accumulated residue of exhibition spaces, to the consistently whimsical approach to objects and site in the practice of Juan Alcazaren and Felix Bacolor, to a devotedly naturalist strain in the work of Genara Banzon and Junyee, and the folk motif-laden work of Roberto Feleo. A parallel development in this regard is the emergence of painting coupled with installative elements. This has surfaced in the work of Annie Cabigting, Jonathan Ching, Bembol dela Cruz, Nona Garcia, Lyra Garcellano, Geraldine Javier, Yasmin Sison, and Gerardo Tan, among other artists tracing their roots to conceptualism.

Possibly among all extant fields of work, installation practice exhibits the most visible tendency in which artists no longer abide by the logic of merely one medium nor technique. Apart from developing in artists a more acute sense of space, material, and the contexts of engagement made possible in often immersive and multisensory encounters inclusive of performance, video, sound, and lately even taste and odor, installation continues to provide a symbolic respite for artists looking to move away from easy commoditization and containment. Over the last decades, practice in this vein has been done by artists such as Poklong Anading, Alfredo and Isabel Aquilizan, Datu Arellano, Martha Atienza, Yason Banal, Joe Bautista, Ringo Bunoan, Marina Cruz, Kiri Dalena, Tad Ermitaño, Patricia Eustaquio, Katya Guerrero, Jose Inocencio III, Nikki Luna, Lani Maestro, Manny Montelibano, Gary-Ross Pastrana, Claro Ramirez, Juni Salvador, Maria Taniguchi, Mac Valdezco, Oscar Villamiel, Eric Zamuco, to name just a few. Senior artists such as Agnes Arellano, Santiago Bose, Roberto Chabet, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Jose Tence Ruiz, among others, have continued to practice with a keen spatial and semiotic sense, and have, over the years, influenced the work of younger practitioners.

Despite or perhaps because of the aggressive take-up of new media, a resiliently folk-privileging stream of work has gathered adherents among artists such as Leslie de Chavez, Riel Hilario, and Rodel Tapaya. Their themes and work processes are variably informed by notions of craft and locus. Operating in hybrid secular-spiritual or metaphysical registers, their work also have affinities in various degrees with the assemblage-installations and freestanding sculpture of Joel Alonday, Renato Habulan, Mark Justiniani, Michael Muñoz, Dan Raralio, Norberto Roldan, Jose Tence Ruiz, Cristina Taniguchi, and Mark Valenzuela.

Painting and sculpture of a visibly expressionist lineage have also been resolutely practiced since the rise to art world attention of the works of artists such as Danilo Dalena, Jaime de Guzman, and Onib Olmedo. This earlier generation gave rise to the 1990s strain of expressionist political critique evident in the early paintings of Elmer Borlongan and Emmanuel Garibay. A far-off but logical counterpart in sculpture may be seen in the work of Roedil Geraldo of Talisay, Negros Occidental, whose likely nearest influence is Black Artists in Asia’s Charlie Co. Parallel to these developments too has been the emergence of an even newer generation of feminist artists circulating in expanding circles while still practicing in the orbit of the more senior founders of Kasibulan. Among these later-generation artists whose works range from installation, performance art, painting, photography, and film are artists such as Nana Buxani, Aba Dalena, Racquel de Loyola, Irma Lacorte, Lea Lim, Vivian Limpin, Aze Ong, Alma Quinto, and Katti Sta. Ana.

The urgency and possibility of change partly unleashed in pre- to post-EDSA’s fleetingly euphoric landscape also underlies much of the experimentation in context and form that has taken place. Such nascent undertakings would be realized in the slew of forward-looking galleries, institutions, and laboratory-type artist spaces, which rose and dissipated while enabling explorations that crossed divides defined along political and sometimes aesthetic alliances. Pinaglabanan, for instance, would have shows curated both by Chabet and Valenzuela at various junctures of the space’s history; those reared in early Art Lab undertakings would cross over both into conceptual and SR-inclined initiatives. That these crossovers extended to succeeding generations of collectives, spaces, and individuals may be seen in the works of artists Anading and Kiri Dalena, among others.

Just as they were dealing with the increasingly complex notions of what constituted art and what distinguishes Filipino culture, artists have also been tapping into both the formal and meaning-evocation potential of materials and physical and social processes. These may be discerned in the visceral decay and chemically breaking down of elements in the work of Dick Daroy and the collaged pop and art references strewn across the works of Nemo Aguila, Andres Barrioquinto, Mariano Ching, R.M. de Leon, Kiko Escora, Dina Gadia, Epjay Pacheco, Jucar Raquepo, Clairelynn Uy, and the Ventura brothers Manok, Ronald, and Olan, alongside the punk sensibility present in the cheeky paintings and constructions of Louie Cordero, Robert Langenegger, Romeo Lee, Manuel Ocampo, Jayson Oliveria, and others.

Broadening the Spheres of Visual Culture. Artists today have crossed and transcended media categories, challenging traditional barriers created by curators and artists. Even as the more traditional modes of practices in painting and sculpture have persisted, they have also, in a sense, mutated in response to new materials, modes of work, and technology being explored and retooled by artists. And so, while there is still the strong homespun vignette flavor in the works of artists like Jecky Alano, Aba Dalena, Ral Arrogante, Michael Cacnio, Susanito Sarnate, and a hagiographic persuasion behind the sculpture of Toym and Juan Sajid Imao, one would also find these artists intermittently veering into relatively untried territory in relation to their own practices. One concrete instance of how the traditional craft of drawing is taken in an unexpected direction is in Renato Orara’s Library Bookworm series where his drawings are surreptitiously done on the pages of books he then inserts or sites within libraries.

Meanwhile, rapid technical advances that have become increasingly accessible to a greater number of artists and publics have also played into the shaping of work done in other fairly staple media like photography whose variably conceptual and documentary strains are evident in the works of artists such as Anading, Datu Arellano, Xyza Bacani, Juan Caguicla, Lena Cobangbang, Neil Daza, Christina Dy, Tommy Hafalla, Wawi Navarroza, Gina Osterloh, Paul Pfeiffer, Steve Tirona, VJ Villafranca, and MM Yu. On the other hand, time-, site-, and motion-sensitive media—like performance, video, sound, and digital interfaces—continue to find ways to coexist with lower-tech as well as more technologically sophisticated production. This broad and often unpredictable pairings and juxtapositions are demonstrated in the works of Anading, Pablo Biglang-Awa, Charles Buenconsejo, Cobangbang, Bunoan, Ermitaño, Cocoy Lumbao, M.O.B. (Mail Order Bride), Renan Ortiz, Bong Ramilo, and Tito and Tita, among others.

An illustrative case of an artist unselfconsciously crossing over into several media is the Baguio-based John Frank Sabado whose early work consisted of intricately crafted painting and threaded assemblages heavily drawing from the indigenous textile-weaving motifs of the Cordilleras. His embarking on performance in the guise of his avatar, Eco-warrior, is indicative of the healthy restiveness that thrusts creative practice into other modes responsive to the production context in which an artist moves within. It also demonstrates how artists who are identified advocates of traditional practices are not held back from changing the pace and method in their own work.

The notion of art exclusively being the sphere for the trained is one of the most challenged ideas of this period. This has certainly been aided by the onset of more accessible imaging technology from digital online platforms and parallel photography/graphic manipulation app portals, alongside widened circulation circuits. Populist-oriented social media applications have, for instance, allowed the rise of tech-savvy segments of the population who not only explore the use of these new creative tools but also short-circuit channels that guard the art world and/or make new art worlds freed from critical restraint.

This relatively autonomous do-it-yourself impulse appears to be behind such initiatives as a recent Bacolod-based sidewalk intervention done by Jose Inocencio III across the Negros Museum during the 2015 VIVA ExCon. This stream runs strongly too in the work of the Negros-based collectives Temple of the Kings and Syano, as well as in the work of the Cagayan de Oro-based Siete Pesos collective, and still other Mindanao-based artists like Ib’n Salipyasin Ahmad, Rosalie Zerrudo, among others.

Whereas most art schools/academies in the Philippines are still organized through the logic of single-form majors, like studio inclusive of painting, sculpture, etc., and visual communication alternately called advertising, a core of newer schools have sprung up since. Decidedly gone multimedia if not transmedia, these schools have also opened up fairly new art management/curatorial programs where both potential artists, curators, and cultural workers receive institutional training as well as input from professional artists, programmers, etc. This rise of transmedia and interdisciplinary school and post-school platforms is prefaced by a continually evolving landscape of practice, which includes guild-type or workshop-collaborative learning models that nurtured the career of those from Salakai in the 1990s, and artist-workers of Broke in the 2000s.

Much more recently in this last decade, a discursive and later termed as research-based strain of art practice would surface in various platforms. This non-spectacle, process-based, and performative stream could be seen as displaying affinities with conceptual work of artists like Judy Freya Sibayan. The more logical antecedents are her projects such as the mobile and body-scaled Scapular Gallery Nomad and the Museum of Mental Objects, a conceptual archive of ideas peer-accessioned by mostly artists associated with Sibayan. This moving away from the making of objects as primary output, the self-directed research-based work that even has avowedly anti-object strain, presently manifests in archiving, workshops, radio broadcasts, talks, screenings, and performances. While still in a nascent stage, this proposed foil to wholesale co-optation by market mechanisms is still largely under-theorized and more commonly construed as public programming or art education rather than creative practice. Nevertheless, among the schooled visual artists who have taken to this vein is Calubayan who has mined a personal engagement with psychotherapy to research and embody the knowledge-accretion process behind what artists do in what appears to be a lifelong performance. In contrast to this inwardly directed impetus of practice is the interventionist and/or participatory/community-oriented work undertaken by W.A.L.A., and other urban collectives who have resorted to a range of modes from one-off occupations of sites, to more socially immersive engagements with disadvantaged social sectors.

As can be gleaned from this survey, emergent initiatives often consist of productions of composite works invoking old-new subjects, employing traditional as well as repurposed and new materials, and/or low and cutting-edge technology as artists look at what is on hand in their effort to reconfigure the parameters of their practices and sites in which they may choose to make and circulate their work.
